Attention: Education Branch

Dear Sir:

Re: Roofs - Old Sun School.

The heavy winds in this country have played havoc with the tar and gravel roofs of this institution and it was only this spring, when there has been a very great deal of rain, that it was noticed that they leaked badly in spots, especially when there was a heavy storm driving from the north. As they will, no doubt, gradually get worse and possibly seriously damage plaster, I have asked the local contractor, Mr. Michael, to give me a price on repairs.

I attach hereto Mr. Michael's estimates of the cost of supplying material and doing this work.

Awaiting your instructions, I remain,

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

The Armature of the 1 H.P. Delco Electric Motor on the pumping plant at the Old Sun School has burned out and the motor is otherwise damaged, when it was overheated by the short circuit.

Another motor was borrowed to operate this plant, while the damaged one was sent to the Bruce Robinson Electric, Calgary, general agents for Delco products. This company now reports that it will cost between $25.00 and $30.00 to install a new armature and generally recondition this motor.

Will authority be granted to have this work done?

Your obedient servant,

Attention: Education Branch

Dear Sir:

Re: Old Sun Indian School.

There are certain repairs and replacements that are necessary at this institution and some work that should be done if funds are available. May I be permitted to enumerate?:

(1) The upright water heating boiler has been leaking badly for the past month but it was kept in use until the school closed. The tubes have been rolled three times but are now beyond repair as they are leaking from the sides into the firebox; there is no alternative but to retube it. This boiler is a necessity and unfortunately is costly to keep in condition because of the soda and alkali in the water. No doubt the proper thing to do would be to install a water softener - but the initial expense is considerable. I inquired of the local steam fitter, L. Michael, and he states that he is prepared to take down the boiler, retube it and erect it again for the sum of $160.00.

(2) The ashes from the big furnaces must be removed by buckets which are hauled to the surface with a windlass. The existing buckets have been in use for ten years -- there are two. They are now absolutely beyond repair and for some months every scheme has been tried to improvise a method of removal, but to no satisfaction. A pair of heavy iron buckets, with strong blacksmith iron handles, can be secured for about $25.00.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
(3) The shaft, pinions and cogs of the Delco pump engine over the second well at the school have been cut by the sand and alkali water until they are so bad that they should be replaced. It is anticipated that these will cost about $20.00.

(4) It has been the policy at this school to do a certain amount of interior painting each summer and the Department has supplied the material. A very good job has always been done and I would recommend that authority to purchase the following paint and painting material be granted, if funds are available:

- Spar Varnish 5 gals.
- Shellac 2 gals.
- Inside White 5 gals.
- Inside Ivory 5 gals.
- Russet Brown 4 gals.
- Battleship Grey 2 gals.

- Boiled Linseed Oil 10 gals.
- Turpentine 10 gals.
- White enamel 2 gals.
- Three inch Brushes 2
- One inch Brushes 2
- Lamp Black 5 lbs.

If authority for the above is granted, it would be appreciated if it was not delayed, so that work can proceed immediately.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
G. M. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Ottawa, July 15, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to repairs and replacements required at the Old Sun Indian Residential School.

Eight hundred dollars ($800.00) was provided for necessary repairs and improvements and new equipment at this school during the current fiscal year. Of this amount, approximately $200.00 has been expended, leaving a balance of $600.00 available.

You may, therefore arrange the following:

1. Take down the upright water heating boiler, retube it and erect it again, for an amount of $160.00. Provided you consider this cost is reasonable.

2. Purchase two heavy iron buckets with strong blacksmith iron handles, at a cost of $25.00

3. Replace shaft, pinions and cogs of the Delco pumping engine, at a cost of $20.00.

The Purchasing Agent is being requested to secure the paint and painting materials. It is noted that the painting will be done by the school staff, without cost to the Department.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent,
Gleichen, Alberta.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I attach account in favour of L. Michael, Gleichen, Alta., for $199.52. Of this amount $129.52 covers the cost of materials purchased. The reasons for authorizing this expenditure are as follows:

2. The Delco pump on the main well filled with water and the bearings and pins burnt out. These had to be supplied immediately.

3. Heavy winds during the latter part of April played havoc with the tar and gravel roofs and in order to avoid damage to the interior of the building the roofs had to be repaired at once.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JULY

SCHOOLS

All children were on holidays but both institutions were visited. At the Crowfoot school an inspection was made of the heating plant which has been in use for some 30 years and needed repairs badly. I am pleased to say that authority has been given for these repairs to be done and it is expected that the plant will be in good working order when school opens.

The same condition, only on a smaller scale, existed at the Old Sun School, this work is now done. The crops at both schools is very good; at the Old Sun a good crop of Alfalfa is being harvested while at the Crowfoot the Rev. Father Riou purchased about 80 tons of prairie hay from the Indians to augment the feed which he will harvest off the farm.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

The Principal has today given me the information that the appropriation for Old Sun Residential School for the present fiscal year is $1200.00, covering repairs and equipment. If such is the case, there are immediate requirements:

1. Paint and painting material, as per the attached list, which should not exceed $125.00; labour to be supplied by the school.

2. An amount not exceeding $750.00 should be provided to purchase building materials for a workshop. This institution must have some place to carry out the program of training as outlined by Mr. Doucet. They now have a qualified woodwork instructor on the Staff but there is no place to carry on instruction. During the visit of Mr. Doucet various schemes for providing accommodation were considered working or the assumption in all cases that suitable land was available. The writer was requested that a disused four-room Indian house might be moved to the school for the purpose; though such a building was not the best, it would be better than none. However, now that there appears to be an amount set aside in the estimates sufficient to supply the materials for a proper workshop it does not seem to suggest itself to move the old building, which would require a foundation and repairs amounting to two or three hundred dollars, and then never be the proper place to carry out a full course of training. If the sum of $750.00 can be supplied with which to purchase building material, it will be excellent training for the pupils of the school to erect a proper type workshop, under capable supervision.

As something must be done immediately, and as the estimates for the fiscal year 1942/43 must go forward at once, please advise by wire or Air Mail whether or not the foregoing expenditures will be allowed.

Your obedient servant,

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 22, 1941.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of the 19th instant and have noted your recommendations. We are sending the list of your requirements, as stated in your requisition, to the Purchasing Agent.

With regard to the erection of a new workshop, valued at $750.00, it is believed that this is not desirable at this time. It is considered that the unoccupied house with the adjoining barn, agreed upon at the time of Mr. Doucet's visit, would prove quite satisfactory. The Department is prepared to approve an expenditure not to exceed $200.00 for the foundations and repair of the above-mentioned building.

We would like you to proceed without delay to the preparation of the foundations for the building and then to its transportation. We wish to have this building ready as soon as possible, in order that the children may not be delayed in their training.

Earlier this month the Principal of the Old Sun School advised me that the kitchen matron was finding it impossible to bake bread without burning it. Furnaceman L. Dear Sir:

The drainage system of the residential part of the Old Sun School has been blocked and waste water from the roof and laundry of the residence has been running into the basement. I made an inspection with the local plumber and found no other way to get at the trouble but to chop holes in the concrete floor. The first hole, based on experience from former similar trouble, did not make it possible to clean the drain and further cutting is being done in the direction of the disposal system. So far, the pipes wind around with many elbows, rises and dips, but it is expected that it can be eventually cleaned.

The foregoing is mentioned so that you might realize the difficulties encountered and the likely cost of around $30.00 in clearing this. As it was an emergency I instructed the plumber to go ahead.

Dear Sir:

I have your voucher No. 524 amounting to $170.60 in connection with plumbing repairs at the Old Sun School. I note that this expenditure was incurred from time to time throughout the past year. However, it now amounts to a considerable sum and it will be difficult for us to explain to the Purchasing Branch why authority was not obtained previous to the expenditure being incurred. Dear Sir:

Would it be possible to state what funds are available during the current fiscal year for development and repairs at the Old Sun Residential School?

Of immediate necessity are: (1) Motor Jack and repair to barn pump. Recently this was temporarily repaired at a cost of $30.00 and this will be repeated if the unit is not properly equipped. The estimated cost of this is $80.50.

(2) The Principal brought to the attention of Inspector Schmidt the desirability and need of a water tank and pump for a vegetable garden. It is noted that the estimated cost of this is $217.00 and that it requires a galvanized tank and 350 feet of pipe. The Blackfoot Coal Mine will have the pipe and possibly a pumping unit for sale very shortly as a larger unit is being installed there. It is doubtful if the galvanized tank could be purchased now and I believe this unit would be more efficient. The whole thing could be purchased for considerably less than the amount estimated.

(3) Paint, to the value of $125.00, is also required so that it may be applied during the summer holidays.

Dear Sir:

I have to report that the tar and gravel roofs on the Old Sun School have been leaking badly in various places. In company with the Principal and local Tinsmith I inspected the building today; the walls of the residence, the two senior dormitories and the senior classroom which where recent rains had seeped through and discolored them. The Principal said that the water was so bad in these parts of the building during a sharp shower on the 13th that the pupils had to get out of bed and mop it up. On inspecting the roof, the flashing appeared to be in excellent condition but the tar had melted and considerable run away down the drain leaving the paper with very little gravel or tar on it in spots.

None of us have had enough experience with tar roofs to know exactly what the condition is nor where the leak might be and this letter is written to ask authority to secure the services of a capable roofing contractor to inspect it. The name of L.D. Reggin, of the Reggin Roofing and Metal Works, Calgary, was suggested. This is a dependable firm.

This matter is considered urgent.

Your obedient servant,

There is no doubt that a certain amount of repairs would give some results, but would not be a job which could be guaranteed, as with patch jobs we simply undertake to do the best we can under the circumstances.

If it is your wish, we would be pleased to carry out repairs in the prominent weak spots to the best of our ability, and as far as we deal this type of work warrants, in order that there may be a degree of satisfaction along with it.

Mr. G. H. Gooderham, Indian Agent, Gleichen, Alberta.

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, enclosing voucher No. 498.

On reviewing this voucher it is found that all the items mentioned in your letter of May 26, 1942, had been purchased two months before. It would be appreciated if you would let me know why this information was not contained in your letter to which reference has just been made. When issuing the authority given in official letter of May 30, the Department was under the impression that the purchases had not yet been made.

What has been said regarding the November 4 item applies also to the charges of November 5 and November 10, also November 26. A full explanation regarding the apparently heavy charges for labour will be necessary before payment of the account can be made.

More detailed information will be necessary regarding the item of $28.00 for repairs on November 22. In the case of all items regarding labour, it will be necessary to show the number of hours the workman was employed and the rate per hour. This applies also to the account of February, 1943.

I am returning both these accounts in order that the necessary explanations may be supplied. I would appreciate receiving your reply at the earliest possible date, in order that, if it is decided to pay the accounts, cheque may be issued from the 1942-43 appropriation.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Reference yours 104-1-5 of the 1st instant and attached voucher number 498.

None of the items mentioned in my letter of May 26, 1942 were purchased until the dates stated in the accounts submitted by Mr. Micheal; these were either in the latter part of 1942 or early in 1943 as you will note.

In regard to the pump-jack, Mr. Micheal had great difficulty in securing it and when it arrived was so busy on other jobs that he did not get it installed. It must be repeated that your authority of May 30, 1942 exceeded the amount expended and furthermore the amount of repairs of $90.65 is just equal to the value of pipe (the property of the Blackfoot Indians) for which no charge has been made.

Now with regard to the repair account for $90.65 I report as follows:

(a) All walls in the Old Sun School are metal lath and plaster; when constructed fittings were attached to walls by screws in wooden plugs. In time these dried out and heavy sinks could not be maintained in place. This was particularly true in the Dairy and to remedy this defect bolts have been put through the wall from another room, with plates to anchor them. The wall used in this case, is solid brick and it took some time to drill necessary holes; the material used, as noted, was negligible but skilled labour was required as there was neither skilled labour nor necessary tools in the institution.

OVER.
(b) The rate of pay in all cases, where not formerly indicated, were $1. per hour. This may seem a lot but Mr. Micheal is an excellent mechanic and wastes no time.

(c) In regard to repairs to a 2 H.P. motor - This is part of the return unit of the heating system. The unit was installed the year following construction of the school, as the heating system was defective. This motor carried a heavy load for 10 years then ceased to function until repaired. The repairs were satisfactory and as the motor is an absolute necessity for heating the institution, the cost was considerably less than replacement.

Indian Agent.

(b) Gravel used on the roof, is of the pit run variety, and has apparently never been screened. It contains silt and loam in far greater proportions than could be considered wind deposited and is not bonded by pitch to the felt.

(d) Galvanized iron flashings have pulled loose from their horizontal wall joints and require soldering at their vertical joints.

(e) Roof hoppers require resetting and in some instances should be replaced.

July 29th, 1943.

Re: Old Sun Indian Residential School
Blackfoot Indian Agency
Sleichen, Alberta.

Inspection of roof of main school building.

Present Condition of Roof

During every heavy rain water runs down the walls of the Principal's residence both to the upper and lower floors and has discoloured and caused cracks in plaster. This also happens to the walls along the south side of the girls' dormitory room and water has leaked down along the lighting fixture in the centre of the room. Some leakage was also noted in the boys' dormitory room at the south end of the main building and also in the chapel which occupies the top floor of the west wing of the building.

All gravel roofs on main building were carefully examined. The appearance of the tar and gravel on the roofs indicates that over much of the area -
(a) the pitch originally applied to the top of the paper did not stick.
(b) the gravel applied was pit run and not properly cleaned and screened.

In many places there is no covering above the paper whatever. In other places there is a layer of fine sand and loam next to the paper, then a half inch layer of pitch mixed with fine sand and gravel above the fine material. This fine material has no pitch in it and prevents a bond between the gravel and tarpaper. All roofs have the appearance of a bad job. There are numerous cracks through the pitch and here and there these cracks extend through the paper permitting the entrance of water.

Cold or wet weather may have prevailed during the time the coat of pitch and gravel was being applied. The entire roof areas, in my opinion, contain far more fine silt and loam than could have been expected to have been deposited by wind blown dust.

The roof drains here and there should be reset and in places renewed. Pitch has run down and plugged some of them.

The flashing appears to be in good condition throughout but in places has become loose from the bricks and in other places needs to be resoldered at the joints. Leaks have developed here and there under the bottom of the flashing which is not bonded to the roof at bottom but extends out over the edge of where paper and brick meet, somewhat like an awning.

Recommendations

Patching in a general way is out of the question as it would be very difficult to determine where to patch as there are cracks in the gravel and pitch everywhere.

I would recommend:

(A) That all of the old gravel and pitch roof be removed and a new built up roof carrying a twenty year bond be laid. If possible asphalt is to be used in the new roof in preference to pitch.
Should lack of funds for this work make it impossible to lay a new roof as recommended above, then I would recommend that the leaky roofs be repaired in the following manner.

1. All loose gravel, earth, sand and silt to be entirely removed from the roof to be repaired by means of square mouth shovels, wire brooms, and brushes so that no loose or unstuck material whatever remains on the built up paper of the roof.

2. When clean the roof is to be well mopped with R.C.400 asphalt at the rate of .4 gallons per square yard, heated to a temperature of not less than 175° and then coated with washed and screened gravel that will pass a one-half inch screen and to be retained on a No. 4 screen. Additional roofing paper to be applied where necessary to extend from the present roof paper up under flashing to a proper bond with the edge of brick parapet walls.

This treatment to extend over & cover the entire area between parapet walls of any and each roof that is repaired. Care is to be exercised that the hot asphalt penetrates and seals all cracks in the old roof surface.

One or other of the above recommendations should be carried out immediately in order that the leaks be stopped before the fall school term commences.

Any of the above work recommended should be done by a first class roofing firm only. I consider it out of the question to attempt any of this work with a day labour force as we would not have the proper equipment nor could we secure sufficient experienced labour.

(Sgd) W. H. Snelson.

Re: Old Sun Indian Residential School
Blackfoot Indian Agency
Glenchen, Alberta.
Inspection of roof of main school building.

Present Condition of Roof

During every heavy rain water runs down the walls of the Principal's residence both to the upper and lower floors and has discoloured and caused cracks in plaster. This also happens to the walls along the south side of the girls' dormitory room and water has leaked down along the lighting fixture in the centre of the room. Some leakage was also noted in the boys' dormitory room at the south end of the main building and also in the chapel which occupies the top floor of the east wing of the building.

All gravel roofs on main building were carefully examined. The appearance of the tar and gravel on the roof indicates that over much of the area -
the pitch originally applied to the top of the paper did not stick.
the gravel applied was pit run and not properly cleaned and screened.
In places there is no covering above the paper whatever. In other places there is a layer of fine sand and next to the paper, then a half inch layer of pitch with fine sand and gravel above the fine material. Fine material has no pitch in it and prevents a bond between the gravel and tarpaper. All roofs have the appearance of a bad job. There are numerous cracks through the pitch and here and there these cracks extend through the paper permitting the entrance of water.

Cold or wet weather may have prevailed during the time coat of pitch and gravel was being applied. The roof areas, in my opinion, contain far more fine sand and loam than could have been expected to have been covered by wind blown dust.

The roof drains here and there should be reset and the flashing renewed. Pitch has run down and plugged some joints.

The flashing appears to be in good condition except but in places has become loose from the bricks and other places needs to be resoldered at the joints. We have developed here and there under the bottom of

Esq.,
Engineer,
Banff, Alberta.
the flashing which is not bonded to the roof at bottom but extends out over the edge of where paper and brick meet, somewhat like an awning.

Recommendations

Patching in a general way is out of the question as it would be very difficult to determine where to patch as there are cracks in the gravel and pitch everywhere.

I would recommend:

(A) That all of the old gravel and pitch roof be removed and a new built up roof carrying a twenty year bond be laid. If possible asphalt is to be used in the new roof in preference to pitch.

(B) Should lack of funds for this work make it impossible to lay a new roof as recommended above, then I would recommend that the leaky roofs be repaired in the following manner.

1. All loose gravel, earth, sand and silt to be entirely removed from the roof to be repaired by means of square mouth shovels, wire brooms, and brushes so that no loose or unstack material whatever remains on the built up paper of the roof.

2. When clean the roof is to be well mopped with No.400 asphalt at the rate of .4 gallon per square yard, heated to a temperature of not less than 175°, and then coated with washed and screened gravel that will pass a ¼-inch mesh screen and be retained on a No.4 screen. Additional roofing paper to be applied where necessary to extend from the present roof paper up under flashing to a proper bond with the edge of brick parapet walls.

This treatment to extend over & cover the entire area between parapet walls of any and each roof that is repaired. Care is to be exercised that the hot asphalt penetrates and seals all cracks in the old roof surface.

(C) One or other of the above recommendations should be carried out immediately in order that the leaks be stopped before the fall school term commences.

Any of the above work recommended should be done by a first class roofing firm only. I consider it out of the question to attempt any of this work with a day labour force as we would not have the proper equipment nor could we secure sufficient experienced labour.

Assistant Engineer.
Sept. 20th, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Old Sun Indian Residential School,
Blackfoot Indian Agency, Alberta.

I have your memorandum of September 30, in connection with the repairing of the roof at this school. This building was erected by contract in the fiscal year 1929-30 and there was no clause in the specifications requiring a guarantee on the roof. The Surveys & Engineering Branch estimate that the total cost of the work, including supervision and contingencies, will be approximately $2500.00, exclusive of any damage to the roof deck, the extent and cost of which can only be determined when the upper covering is removed.

In view of the report that we have received and the further fact that the Indian Agent has written again urging the installation of a new roof to avoid further damage to the interior of the school, I should appreciate the approval of the Minister to transfer the necessary funds to the Surveys & Engineering Branch, in order that they may proceed with the work, as funds are available.
For your information I may say that an amount of $800.00 was specifically provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at this school. The school management is willing to forgo any expenditures in this regard this year if the new roof is installed.

Director.

Re: Water Supply at the Old Sun Residential School

About two weeks ago there was a noticeable decrease in the amount of water pumped from the two wells which supply this large institution and in the last week the supply decreased to a point where it was impossible to carry water to the upper floors even when no water was used in the laundry.

Mr. Snelson of the Engineering Branch, Banff was here inspecting the roof of this school and the situation was discussed with him. It was agreed that the water level must be lowered and an examination of the pump and equipment must be made.

The services of the local plumber, L. Michael were secured and he has today pulled the pipe of the smaller of the two wells and has found a broken pipe and worn cylinder leathers. Repairs are now being made and this well will be producing again tomorrow.

The larger well will be the real problem. Mr. Snelson is fully familiar with this one as he was called in a few years ago when it was found necessary to reduce the size of the casing and the cylinder. In recent months rods have been broken and this could be caused by air replacing water, or in other words, the water level had dropped and the unit continued to pump. The well is supplying some water; the plant is shut down and only operates at intervals for a few short hours.

At present there is 2" cylinders on this pump and there is only one size smaller - 15/8". It is possible that the pump could be operated continually with this smaller cylinder.
As this was considered an emergency I authorized Michael to order the cylinder. The total cost of repairs, parts and labour to the two wells will amount to about $50. It is hoped that this will be approved.

Indian Agent,
G. H. Gooderham
Ottawa,
November 26, 1943.

REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Agriculture:

Very little was done on the farms and many of the Indians had moved to winter quarters, or the coal mine, or to work off the reserve. Some grain was delivered under the quota system to Railhead and some feed was hauled to the stock camps. A large quantity of feed was cut and hammer-milled at the hospital farm, Farm B and Farm 4 feed lots.

Feed & Water:

Owing to the mild weather, large sloughs and the river were open. Some work was done on farm wells and a few wells in the river flats were put down or deepened. At the Old Sun Residential School, the water supply was low and conservation measures had to be employed to look after the needs of this institution. It is believed that the very dry season has lowered the water level, especially shallow wells. There is no suffering from the lack of water.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

RE: Old Sun Res. School Septic System.

On the 8th, I inspected the disposal plant at Old Sun School at the request of the principal. I found that it was plugged and the source of the trouble was not visible. He had endeavoured to clear by the usual methods with schoolboy labour but with no results. Sewage was backing into the school, therefore some immediate action was necessary.

The services of two good Indians was secured and they started digging around the various tanks and then along the pipe line. They worked the balance of the week and got it sufficiently operative to clear the school.

Another inspection was made today after consultation yesterday with the local plumber, L. Michael.

The large chamber had been uncovered, we found the sewage is partly solidified and it must be bailed out before the system will operate properly again. Also found quite a few 6" and 8" glazed tile broken; these must be renewed before the line is covered in again.

Made arrangements for the purchase of 40' of 8" and 20' of 6" tile from Medicine Hat and the Indians are proceeding to clear out chamber.

The cost of the tile and replacing by a competent man will be about $50.00 and it is estimated that the labour will cost $150.00, therefore the total cost will be $200.00.

(OVER)
The system was installed in 1930; water plus tar, sand and gravel off the big roof has slowed up the action of the plant and existing conditions had to be dealt with as quickly as possible. It was only today that the actual condition was known. Trust it was in order to proceed.

Could an accountable cheque of $150.00 be air-mailed to pay for labour? These workmen will not wait for their wages. They receive 50¢ per hour.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

You will know that when Old Sun Residential School, on the Blackfoot Reserve, was destroyed by fire in June, 1928, that it was impossible to rebuild at that time until the Blackfoot Indians consented to loan $90,000.00 from their interest account to enable the work to proceed. The Department paid $40,000.00 from Appropriation and $50,000.00 from the funds of the Blackfoot Band, with the expectation that this money would be returned to the Band account. Owing to financial stringencies the money has not been returned to the account and it is considered that the Indians' interest in the building should be protected by placing fire insurance thereon.

Accordingly it has been decided to place $40,000.00 fire insurance on the building itself in which the Indians have an interest, no insurance on the contents. You should consult Mr. C. A. McKinnon, Insurance Agent, of Drumheller, Alberta, to have this insurance placed on the building for $40,000.00. You should be able to give Mr. McKinnon full particulars as to the construction of this building which is considered fireproof. There is also water provided in case of fire and other precautions taken and it should be possible to secure a low rate of fire insurance on such building. It is advisable that the Insurance Agent himself should go over the building to determine the class of risk on which he is placing the insurance. The policy should be made to read that loss, if any, is payable to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and be forwarded here.

Your obedient servant,

(SIG) A. F. MACKENZIE

Secretary.

September 6, 1928.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 31st ult., I enclose herewith the petition which the Blackfoot Indians signed in connection with the building of a new school.

The petition was taken around the Reserve by the Revd. Mr. Gimney at the request of the Chiefs. Before he did so, he asked me if it was in order and I stated that I could see no objection. The Chiefs and some of the Indians who are Protestants approached me at the same time and stated that in their belief, the Members of the Band would be glad to ask the Department to loan sufficient money from Band Funds to erect the school, provided it could be built this year. The petition was completed and handed to me by Mr. Gimney on August 4th.

The Indians want a school and at that time (July) were afraid that the children might be sent to other schools. Even if a school could not be provided during the present school year, I am satisfied that the Indians are prepared to advance necessary funds to proceed with construction in time to allow occupancy in the fall of 1929.

It is hoped that Day-schools can be started by October 1st at the latest. If the Indians keep their promise, the pupils of Old Sun's will continue school work as usual. Health conditions will be watched and the Church authorities have supplied considerable clothing from other points for the children of the poor parents who cannot purchase necessary clothing.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1944.

Schools;

During this month, preparations for the fall term was the order of the day at the schools. Plant and equipment was checked and necessary repairs, additions and replacements made, where possible. Painting and cleaning was done.

At The Old Suns there are a number of changes in staff. This is the only Anglican school in Western Canada, with a full staff and they look a capable lot. The farm at this school was badly hailed but a good crop of feed has been harvested including native hay and alfalfa. Some grain is being threshed and the garden will supply requirements.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re Old Suns Res. School Water Supply.

The supply of water to this institution has been below normal for the past three weeks.

The Principal and staff checked plant to the best of their ability and increased the air pressure with the aid of a motor unit from the Agency; there was only temporary improvement and for some days the pressure has been low and water can only be supplied in limited quantity to the basement and ground floors.

It is feared that the water level and supply in one of the wells has dropped and possibly the table is lower in all three wells. However, there is nothing to substantiate this surmise until the plants are thoroughly checked. I have therefore secured the services of two mechanics to pull pipe and check all plants. They are not the men usually employed as their services are not available.

The situation can be very serious but it is hoped all available water in the two wells connected to the main building will be saved when the plants are in perfect running condition. If not, will authority be given to get Mr. Snelson of the Engineering Branch, Banff, to inspect it, please.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Dec. 8th, 1944.

Mr. Gooderham,
Indian Agency,
Blackfoot Reserve.

Dear Mr. Gooderham,

My enrollment has reached a point where I am having to get two more members of my staff. We increased by one some time ago and in order to accommodate her I had to equip one bedroom with children's furniture. I need this now so I am without the necessary beds and furniture for three rooms. Could you please ask the Department for authority to purchase the following articles to equip these rooms:

3 Steel beds with springs - 3'x7'13" - walnut finish.
3 Mattresses - 6'x3'3" - spring filled.
6 Pillows.
2 Dressers with mirrors - walnut finish.
2 Wash stands - walnut finish.
6 Occasional arm chairs.
3 common bedroom chairs.

Our Staff sitting room is also very inadequately equipped. We have only three wicker arm chairs and a wicker settee for two. These are by no means comfortable and only accommodate five out of the twelve staff members. Our ladies work much harder than most people in ordinary jobs and need some measure of comfort in their off hours. Would you please ask for authority to purchase:

2 Chesterfield sets complete. (2 couches & 4 arm chairs)
The best kind to get for an institution like this would be some like we have in officers messes - leather and substantial. There should be a number of these available now.

A number of our children are now taking piano lessons and we have no piano in the school. At present I am lending one of my own for this purpose. Can you also bring this to the notice of the Department and ask them to provide us with one.

Yours very sincerely,

SIG. JOHN W. HOUSE.
Principal.

Attention Schools Section:

An explanation is due on Vouchers No. 184 and No. 185.

There is a 50 tube upright boiler in use at the Old Suns Residential School; it supplies all hot water for the institution.

Early in the year it commenced to leak and A. T. Robinson, a boiler man, was employed to repair it. He could only do a temporary job as the tubes were old and many were beyond re-rolling. It was kept in use till the middle of June when it would no longer hold water.

Cranes Ltd. was contacted and fortunately had sufficient long length pre-war tubing to renew this unit. This was ordered with a gate valve to replace a leaky one connected with the large water line to the main heating boilers.

Then Robinson and a helper were employed to retube it and put in new connections. The whole is now as good as new.

The work is well done and the time includes the early repair work. The cost appears to be high but the services of qualified men are now at a premium.

The Vouchers are submitted for payment.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 31st, 1945.

August 17, 1945.

The Indian Agent,
Blackfoot Reserve,
Gleichen,

Dear Mr. Gooderham:

I am enclosing estimates for 1946 - 1947. You will note that I have transferred item 3 - Pig Pen - from 1945 - 1946 estimates to next year because it is impossible to get lumber for building and the price is out of all reason.

The money thus saved from this year's authority could be far more profitably spent in things which could be procured from the War Assets Corporation - the following:

1. Piano
2. Flat work ironer - 4 ft. electric.
3. Bread Cutter
4. Potato Peeler
5. 30 cwt. stake body Truck
6. Jeep
7. Two Chesterfield Suites - leather.

Re the piano and chesterfield suites, I wrote you on December 8, 1944 and the Department replied December 26, 1944 asking us to draw this to their attention in the present fiscal year when they hoped to be able to furnish them.

The other things are suggested in order to meet the greatest problem in Indian Schools - that is spending so much time in chores that there is little time for real instruction. All Indians complain about this and we know their complaints are justified by fact, yet the Schools cannot do anything about it if the Department will not provide labour saving devices.

In this School five children work four days each week trying to get clothes and bedding ironed. One hundred hours per week heating and pushing old fashioned pad irons. The whole lot could be done in a few hours with a good four foot electric flat ironer.
Bread cutting for each meal takes three girls half an hour with knife and bread board. That is a total of 3½ hours lost every week in just cutting bread.

Three girls spend all of every morning peeling potatoes and cutting and cleaning vegetables—a total of nine hours per week per child.

Most of this could be eliminated with proper machines. The Army provided these things in their camps and it would be the course of wisdom for the Department to do the same for Indian Schools.

The reason for suggesting a thirty hundred weight truck and jeep is that our farm is one and a half miles away from the school. We waste two hours every day going to and coming from work. With an average of five boys and a farm instructor this means a loss of twelve hours every day. It also means very many hours spent in farming that would not be necessary if we were properly equipped.

Would you please find out if authority is granted for painting the barn. It was in 1945-1946 Estimates but I have not heard anything about it. Paint is procurable and all our buildings are beginning to look shabby.

Yours very sincerely,

Signed JOHN W. HOUSE

Principal
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Ottawa, 30th August, 1945.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Indian Agent, Gleichen, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant enclosing copy of letter which you received from the Principal of Old Sun Indian Residential School.

The Department is prepared to purchase a Flat Work Ironer, however, we would like to know the voltage and frequency of the electric current which will be used. If possible quote the catalogue number of some firm or any other information that will assist our Purchasing Branch in securing the equipment.

The Department also recommends the purchase of a piano. I have noted the Principal's arguments in connection with the purchase of a Bread Cutter and Potato Peeler but I am doubtful if we can obtain approval for the purchase of these two items.

With reference to the request for two Chesterfield suites, please let me know if these are to replace an old suite or are they intended as a new issue.

Regarding the truck and jeep, this equipment is not purchased by the Department. It has always been purchased by the school management from their own funds. It is possible they may be able to secure this equipment from War Assets Corporation but frankly we have not had any success yet in securing equipment in this manner. However, in view of recent changes in the war situation, it is possible more equipment will be available shortly.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

ATTENTION: Mr. P. Phelan, please.

Reference yours of the 15th instant, file 104-1-5, addressed to the Clerk in Charge, Blackfoot Agency, re a piano purchased for Old Sun's Residential School: This letter was brought to my attention while I was at this Agency, and as Mr. James was not familiar with this, and had nothing whatever to do with it, I asked him not to advise the Principal of Old Sun's School until I had written further about this transaction.

I have been a great many years an Indian Agent, and have always tried to follow instructions as to purchasing, and what not, and in this instance I did not believe I was acting contrary to your desires or assuming responsibility of a purchase which might have been carried out by the Purchasing Agent.

Owing to pressure of other work by the Principal as well as myself, the matter of purchasing a piano for the institution was not seriously considered until I was aware that I would be spending considerable of this year as Acting Inspector, and in order to try and get the purchase through before the end of the fiscal year 1945-46, I had an interview with the Rev. Mr. House, when I told him to contact reliable firms in Calgary. I did not know of any piano available from a private source.

It was known that pianos had increased in price considerably during the War, and I told Mr. House not to exceed the sum of $200.00, which price was as low as could be expected and still get a reasonably good instrument. The Director and yourself must admit that that is not an excessive price to pay, and that to purchase a piano for $100.00 would be very poor business. It is respectfully submitted that $200.00 should be allowed: The Principal has paid more than that, and it is noted that he purchased a bench with the piano. He was directed to the Manager of the T. Eaton Company, and it is our opinion that this gentleman would see that he would get very good value.

(OVER)
As already stated, I take full responsibility for this purchase, and before contacting the School authorities and stating that they must pay everything over $100.00, I would like to have your further comments, please.

G. H. Gooderham,
Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

ATTENTION: Mr. P. Phelan, Please.

Reference yours of the 15th instant, file 104-1-5, addressed to the Clerk-in-Charge, Blackfoot Agency, re a piano purchased for Old Sun's Residential School: This letter was brought to my attention while I was at this Agency, and as Mr. James was not familiar with this, and had nothing whatever to do with it, I asked him not to advise the Principal of Old Sun's school until I had written further about this transaction.

I have been a great many years an Indian Agent, and have always tried to follow instructions as to purchasing, and what not, and in this instance I did not believe I was acting contrary to your desires or assuming responsibility of a purchase which might have been carried out by the Purchasing Agent.

Owing to pressure of other work by the Principal as well as myself, the matter of purchasing a piano for the institution was not seriously considered until I was aware that I would be spending considerable of this year as Acting Inspector, and in order to try and get the purchase through before the end of the fiscal year 1945-46, I had an interview with the Rev. Mr. House, when I told him to contact reliable firms in Calgary. I did not know of any piano available from a private source.

It was known that pianos had increased in price considerably during the War, and I told Mr. House not to exceed the sum of $200.00, which price was as low as could be expected and still get a reasonably good instrument. The Director and yourself must admit that that is not an excessive price to pay, and that to purchase a piano for $100.00 would be very poor business. It is respectfully submitted that $200.00 should be allowed: The Principal has paid more than that, and it is noted that he purchased a bench with the piano. He was directed to the Manager of the T. Eaton Company, and it is our opinion that this gentleman would see that he would get very good value.

(OVER)
2.

Dear Mr. Pugh,

As is customary I am giving you this list of requirements from the Department. It would be a convenience if some action could be taken to procure these before the Summer holidays begin as painting and repairs can best be done when the children are away.

1. Interior paint used by Schools management for upkeep of interior of school. This should be "Bapco" paint because most of the walls are already done with this brand and other kinds cannot be used for patching because they do not blend.

2. Barn fixtures - repairs

- 1 Loudens Letter carrier complete with hoist $100.00
- 13 pairs snap fasteners for Loudens stanchion neck irons
- 1000 feet of lumber - various kinds - for repairs to buildings.

These were in 1946 estimates but unobtainable. They should be procured as soon as possible.
3. Rugs for staff rooms in the School.

4, 9 ft. x 9 ft. Wilton rugs
10, 9 ft. x 7½ ft. Wilton rugs

All staff rooms have bare concrete floors and the Department equipped each room with a rug 17 years ago. These are now beyond repair and the above requisition is for replacement of these. This is long overdue.

4. Singer sewing machines for sewing room.

- 1 Tailor's machine = ?
- 4 Treadle machines = $25.00

The present ones were condemned several years ago, and have been giving a lot of trouble. The above are for replacement.

5. Painting barn and outbuildings.

1 barn and roof
1 cattle shed
1 work shop
1 granary
1 tool shed
2 implement sheds
1 chicken house
1 cottage
1 brooder house

Most of these buildings have not been painted for fifteen years and are a disgrace to a government plant. I would urge that they be done this year without fail.

6. Painting outside of window frames of school

237 windows
237 storm windows
19 doors

Except for a few which can easily be reached on the ground floor, these have had no paint for seventeen years and are beginning to show signs of weather. They should be done right away.

7. For three or four years I have had an item of $900 for a pig pen in my estimates. No Departmental action has been taken about this so I want to cancel it and substitute therefor an implement shed at about the same cost.
We have only an open-sided shed for storing implements for the Winter, and it is usually full of snow. A school of this kind should have a closed-in shed, big enough to store any implement and a workshop (heated) on one end where farm machinery could be over-hauled and repaired during the winter months as part of mechanical training for the boys. In a farming area such as this, no boy should go out of school without a working knowledge of ordinary machine repairs, but this cannot be done without a place large enough to house machinery and repair it during the Winter. Will you please ask the Department to cancel the pig pen, and substitute an implement shed of this nature.

8. Our pyrene extinguishers are so old that quite frequently they stick and will not work immediately. I think we should renew them all before next Winter. That would be -

12 1½ quart pump extinguishers, and
2 doz. Flash Fire Chief automatic extinguishers from the Flash Fire Extinguisher Co.,
10 Diana Court, Winnipeg.

I am attaching an estimate from Mr. Fosson, Turner Valley, for painting the buildings (5 and 6). It looks to be a little high, but there is a lot of surface to cover.

Will you please take these needs up with the Department at your earliest convenience.

Yours very sincerely,

John W. House

Re: Old Sun Indian Res. School.

I beg to enclose herewith letter received from Rev. John W. House, Principal of the Old Sun Indian Residential School which is self-explanatory and I would comment as follows:

1. Interior paint: I would recommend that this should be supplied. Labour will be done by the school. Cost $250.00

2. Barn Fixtures - Repairs: 1 Loudens Letter carrier complete with hoist and 16 pairs snap fasteners. Cost approximately $100.00. I would recommend that this be supplied as soon as convenient. 1000 ft of lumber needed for various repairs. Cost about $90.00

3. Rugs for Staff Rooms: 4, 9 ft x 9 ft Wilton rugs and 10, 9'x 7½', Wilton rugs, the approximate cost $550.00. Principal's remarks self-explanatory.

4. Singer Sewing Machines: 1 Tailor's machine and 4 Treadle machines. Principal's remarks self-explanatory.

5. Painting Barn and Outbuildings: Refer to Principal's remarks.

6. Painting outside of window frames of school: Refer to the Principal's remarks.

7. Re new workshop: It was agreed between the Principal and myself that this Estimate should be properly prepared for 1948-1949 Estimates.

8. Re Fire Extinguishers: 12 - ¼ quart pump extinguishers; 2 dozen Flash Fire Chief automatic extinguishers (Glass self breakable). I would recommend that a representative of a Fire Extinguisher Company be asked to attend school, check all extinguishers, equipment and refill and replace where necessary.

You will note the date of this request and I am slow in sending it in but I informed Rev. House that this should have all been set out in 1947-1948 Estimates.

I am passing this along for the Department's information and that requests Nos. 1, 2, 4 and 8 if possible should be complied with by the Department for immediate attention. If the dept. considers further action, please inform and requisitions will be prepared.

W. P. B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Estimates 1948-49, Old Sun Residential School, Gleichen, Alberta.

Following our recent conversation in your office, I requested all our Principals to consult with your Agents in their areas and submit a list of services urgently required at their schools. Hereunder is the report from our Principal at Gleichen listing the services required in order of urgency.

**UPKEEP OF PLANT**

Emergency repairs to pumping plant, heating system, plumbing and laundry.

Estimated cost for year $400.00

**MAJOR REPAIRS - TUBES FOR BOILER**

The local water eats through the tubes in 2 or 3 years when they suddenly go to pieces and have to be replaced. The present tubes have been installed for about 3 years and need for early replacement is anticipated. Repairs to radiators and traps are also needed.

Estimated cost $300.00

**EXTERIOR PAINTING**

All outside woodwork of the School and of most of the outbuildings have not been painted for about 17 years. As a result the exterior of these buildings is in bad condition and will get worse unless soon protected by painting.

Estimated cost (as given by local painter) $2600.00

**IMPLEMENT SHED**

The school has no closed-in place for repair
of farm implements with the result that pupils who are going to be farmers have no chance of getting practical experience during the winter on farm machinery repairs. A closed-in shed large enough to take heavy farm machinery and which can be heated in winter for use as a repair shop.

Estimated cost $2500.00

RUGS FOR STAFF ROOMS

All these rooms have rough concrete floors. When the School was built in 1929, the Government provided a rug for each staff room but, after over 17 years of wear, they are pretty well worn out. 14 are required at an estimated cost of $550.00

REFILLING OF FIRE EXTINGUISHERS

Estimated cost for year $25.00

The Principal also recommends strongly the provision of labour-saving devices (potato peeler, bread slicer, mixing machine, etc.) advocated by your nutritional experts at a cost of $300-$400. I understand from Colonel Neary, however, that he is giving active consideration to the supply of such devices to all schools.

The Principal has drawn our attention to the deplorable state of his farm machinery, giving as examples his binder which is 1920 vintage and his tractor which scarcely has one original part left on it. I am not certain whether you help in the supply of machinery to schools that operate good-sized farms but if you can, we certainly shall appreciate it.

We shall be glad if you will give the fullest possible consideration to the inclusion of the services mentioned above in your Departmental Estimates for 1948-49. I understand that your Blackfoot Agency is aware of these needs.

Yours truly,

Attached is an account amounting to $585.73 covering the cost of supplying and installing a new pump in the well at the Old Sun Residential School and also emergency repairs to the hot water heating boiler. Approximately $216.00 of the total amount represents expenditure for labour.

The pump and the well had been in operation for approximately twenty hours a day for the past eight years and it had reached such a condition that it was impossible to repair it satisfactorily and a new pump was absolutely essential. The hot water heating boiler gave out about the end of December and it had to be repaired immediately. As a matter of fact, the condition of the boiler and the difficulty of securing necessary supplies necessitated keeping this school closed for a few extra days at Christmas.

I would appreciate it if you would issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows: 516-758-10-691.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Attention of Welfare & Training.

re Old Sun School.

I beg to report that about a month ago the cook stove located in the Farming Instructor's Engineer's house on the grounds of the above school blew up apparently owing to a corroded water front, a very peculiar accident and it was fortunate that the water ran over the floor preventing a fire, at the time there was nobody in the house.

The stove was a purchase by our branch, Mr. Cole, the Principal of the School is now asking for a replacement. This could be discussed with Mr. Gooderham at present in Ottawa as he is conversant with the set up.

Local quotation of a suitable McClary stove with water front—approximately $125.00. If it is allowed I know the local hardware merchant would carry the account till the first of April.

I regret that I seem to be asking for these expenditure when I know your school funds are depleted at the end of the fiscal year.

WPPB.

Re Old Sun Indian School
Principal's Residence,
Re-Furnishing.

I am in receipt of your letter of April 2nd of the above file and beg to enclose herewith Requisition for essential furnishings. The remaining few furnishings have been in use for 17 years and have definitely seen their best days.

In regards to the second bedroom suite, there has always been a guest room in the school but Mr. Cole is now endeavoring to get a third teacher who will occupy the school great room. Any guests of the school will now be occupying a room in the Principal's residence (apartment in the school).

I would further report that in the kitchen of the Principal's residence is a McClary Electric Range which was installed according to statements at the time the school was built in 1898. This electric range is in a very bad state of repair and will have to be put in repair and I would estimate at a cost of approximate $75.00. I doubt the feasibility of repairing this range; a new range could be obtained for about $175.00 to $200.00. (Frigidaire Electric Stove RJ 10 C -4 burners on top $255.00)

Mr. Cole is also asking for an electric washer for his residence in the sum of $160.00, but as your letter did not go beyond furnishing I did not include this item till I hear further from you.

I would take this opportunity of stating I regret the heavy expenditure at the Old Sun School this last three months but it would seem that everything tumbled down all in one fell swoop.

Respectfully submitted,

W.P. Pugh
Supt.
Old Sun Indian Residential School
Gleichen, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

re: 1 H.P. Electric Motor
Bread Mixer

The motor m/n, that has been running for a number of years has keeled over and is completely burnt out. In the emergency I have ordered one from the Bruce Robinson firm of Calgary. I got in touch with the manager but it appears these motors are hard to procure right now.

I suggested to the Indian agent this was his responsibility, however, as he is new to the school work he does not feel it is his obligation. We will fight it out when the motor arrives.

In the meantime we are buying bread as we have no suitable bread mixing tub.

I will forward you a copy of my letter to the Indian agent with a request to meet this account when we get fixed up.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

As the toilets in the room off the boys playroom are in a frightful condition and most unsanitary with drains badly blocked and urinals not working may I suggest an inspection and subsequent report to be tabled to you for consideration by your Department.

Unless the local plumber has power equipment it is doubtful if he can handle the work. However he might be able to present a problem to our solution.

The partitions or cubicles formerly built round each toilet have disappeared and the lady supervisor cannot comfortably check this room daily until these screens are renewed. I have made enquiries about the old ones but no one seems to know what happened to them.

It was suggested we do away entirely with the urinals (now blocked) however with 47 boys in residence I think after further consideration this would be a mistake.

May this matter have your early attention, please.

Yours very truly,

Signed E.S.W. Cole,
Principal.
Old Sun School
Gleichen, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Pugh,

It has been my experience that a word from a Supt. of Agencies has a remarkable effect and from then our supervision is much easier.

Yours truly,

I am in receipt of your two letters of the 4th June and 18th June. I have been conferring with the Principal Rev. E. Cole in this connection and we think we have arrived at considered conclusions.

1. Repair roof house roof only, this roof is now owing in with the excess moisture of this past spring, and I might say this has priority. It is a question of labor with plumbing for the roof, sometimes available, sometimes not so kept up.

2. Replacement of 5 toilet seats for Boys' Toilets at a cost of $15.00 each installed - Total $75.00. These are up swing weighted seats, rise to the vertical position when not in use. 3. Small general repair, also locker seats, material & labor.

4. Repairs to wind mill. Blow down during heavy blow this spring.

5. Repairs to implement shed. No estimate available.

May I suggest that you allow me to purchase the materials locally and employed local skilled help and have account forwarded immediately on completion of the work. Dear Colonel Neary,

Below is an excerpt from a letter written to the Administration by Mr. Cole, the Principal of the Old Sun School, which is self-explanatory.

"While I am indeed most reluctant to advocate capital expenditure of approximately $2,000.00 at this time, I nevertheless feel confident that, if a stoker is installed in this school, it will pay for itself in three years. I have made a careful check on the performance of the Iron Fireman from two users: (a) Roman school here and (b) the S. Army home in Gleichen. I have seen the stoker at the latter place. I suggest the Crowfoot school is a building similar in size with the Old Sun and not heated as comfortably as our school. The Principal of that school only uses one furnace and his fuel bill for six months was about 40% less than ours. Our fuel account for six months, viz: Oct. 1st to March 31st was in the neighborhood of $1300.00, kitchen coal included.

"I have been down to the Indian mines this week and talked this matter over with the Manager, Mr. Marshall; incidentally this chap is an expert on coal as he has spent a lifetime in the work. We can purchase steam coal at the mine for $2.00 per ton plus $2.75 cartage charges; the cartage price has been set by the Indian office. $4.75 per ton of coal at the school is a tempting proposition as c.f. $9.35 f.o.b. Gleichen depot. It is admitted that the B.T.U. Indian mine coal is not rated as high as the Blairmore mines, 9000 as c.f. 1200 per lb. at Blairmore mine. The fact that we can..."
purchase coal on the Reserve for years to come seems to warrant favourable consideration of the installation of a stoker.

"There are other stokers on the market as well as the Iron Fireman but an examination of detail has convinced me the one named is the one for our use. For example, the Iron Fireman has an iron-steel worm drive which grinds the lumps. Other stokers have a brass worm which, while operating silently, does not do the job of rolling the coal through and the brass worm quickly chews up."

"Mr. Michael, the town plumber, is a most reliable tradesman and a job done by him is satisfactory. He did submit tenders for the installation of this stoker years ago but nothing was done about it, worse the pity.

"This stoker is bin-feed and will, or would, be installed to enter the furnace on the south side, thus not interfering with any cleaning operations and an aperture of 2' square would be required to fix the main shaft through the coal bin wall."

The sum of $1900.00 is provided in the Department's estimates for new boiler and painting at the Gleichen school and I respectfully request that the proposition as put forth in Mr. Cole's letter be considered by Indian Affairs Branch. Not only would the installation of an Iron Fireman Stoker result in a considerable saving to the operational costs of the school but it would allow the Principal to purchase and use a type of coal mined on the reserve. Literature is enclosed for your information.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Superintendent.

Dear Mr. King:

Please read what I have to write and help me, I am not asking for anything, but what is rightfully my husband's and we are just about desperate. Mr. Sweeney and I are no longer young and in the last two years my husband's sickness has left us without anything financially.

Back in the late 1920's, Mr. Sweeney built several Indian Schools for the Government everything went along well, 'til the last Indian School was built at Gleichen, Alta. to date we have not had a refund of the deposit which had to be put with the Government. The accumulated interest of all these years it is now quite a sizeable sum of money. My husband is ill and not able to work and that money at our age would keep us going without charity for the rest of our lives.

For the life of me, Mr. King, I can not see why the government would hold up refunding at least the principal. Mr. Sweeney worked hard for that money, all the bills towards that school are paid, I know that, because it just about cleaned us of every nickle we had. We used to a letter a month telling us that the money would be refunded in due course, to date we have had nothing. Those letters were addressed to the Yale Hotel, Calgary.

I am writing this, because, my husband is ill and discouraged. Please help me obtain this money, Mr. King and thank you.

Sincerely,

(Sgd) (Dora Sweeney,

Mrs. J.F. Sweeney,
2503 15 A. St. N.W.,
Calgary, Alta.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Heating of Water
Old Sun Indian Residential School, Gleichen, Alberta.

At the above school the hot water is heated in a jacket heater separate and distinct from the large boilers producing the heat for the buildings.

As it would seem more economical from the standpoint of fuel consumption to utilize the waste heat from the boilers for heating the hot water during the normal heating season, the Principal was asked to look into the matter. He reports that a local plumber considers that this would be too expensive a method because the coils would get quickly corroded and the expense of cleaning them out would not justify their usefulness.

I am not satisfied that the hot water coils would corrode any quicker if incorporated in the main boilers than they would in a separate heater and, in the interest of saving fuel, I would appreciate if you could arrange that the heating engineers of the Department give the matter study at the first convenient opportunity and let us know, through you, what their views are.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

Dear Madam:

I desire to refer to your letter of June 24th addressed to the Prime Minister and also the acknowledgment of his Secretary dated June 29, 1948.

I understand that Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Alberta, interviewed your husband recently in regard to the matter.

From the information contained in your letter, it is understood that you refer to the erection of the Old Sun's Indian Residential School on the Blackfoot Reserve near Gleichen, Alberta, in the year 1930.

Our file indicates that Wyndels Construction Company went into liquidation before the building was completed and the Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada, Winnipeg, Manitoba was appointed to wind up the business with the Department in connection with the Old Sun's School.

In a letter dated July 21, 1930, the Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada informed us in part as follows:

"Please find enclosed two certificates No. 11 and 12 totalling $24,526.63. We also enclose a list of the different amounts due to sub-contractors with authorization from the Wyndels Construction Company to pay these amounts out of these certificates and also out of the deposit made by the Wyndels Construction Company."
The following is a statement of the final settlement:

Certificate No. 11 $14,528.63
Certificate No. 12 10,000.00

TOTAL: $24,528.63

Security Deposit 13,544.75

TOTAL DUE CONTRACTORS: $38,073.38

Payment of Accounts of Sub-contractors 31,882.03

BALANCE DUE: $6,191.35

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

I desire to refer to Mr. Adam's memorandum of June 30th and our acknowledgment of July 5th with reference to a letter received by the Minister from Mrs. J. F. Sweeney of Calgary, Alberta. Enclosed is a draft letter for the Minister's signature. The delay in preparing this communication is due to the fact that we had to search our files and also had to communicate with Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Mr. Gooderham who was Indian Agent at the time on the Blackfoot Reserve, when the Old Sun's Residential School was erected. Mr. Gooderham interviewed Mr. Sweeney, husband of the lady by whom the letter of June 24th was signed. Mr. Sweeney made the following statement to Mr. Gooderham:

"He admitted that his wife had written a letter to Ottawa, which, no doubt, called for the information that you asked me to get. Mr. Sweeney claims that he took over the Windles Construction Company at the death of Mr. Windles at the time the Old Sun School was erected, and so far as he can remember the Company properly completed this contract, therefore the ten percent deposit should have been returned. He said that the Windles Construction Company erected many residential schools.

Mr. Sweeney stated that he and his wife were now in dire circumstances. He is nearly seventy years of age and was recently a patient of the T.B. San. I promised him that I would give you this information. I told him that I doubted that if at this late date, he had any claim which could be met".
On reviewing our files at the time the Old Sun's School was completed in July of 1930, we can find no reference to Mr. Sweeney's name. The information contained in the draft letter which we are forwarding to you has been obtained from our own file.

Director.

I wish to advise you that Mr. Jack Miller called during the absence of Rev. Cole, Principal, Old Sun School, and myself, in regards to the complaint of the above roof. Dear Colonel Neery:

On 20th August during a discussion in your office you advised me that approval had been secured for an expenditure of £1,967.75 for installation of a stoker at Old Sun School.

I passed this information on to the Principal and have a letter today from him pointing out that it will be a great help to him in the matter of coal procurement if your local agent can receive official word from you about this expenditure at an early date. The situation is that the mileage from the school to the Indian Reserve Mine via the ferry (replacing the bridge carried out last spring and which will not be replaced until late next winter) is only 24 miles but, after the ferry ceases operating and until the new bridge is in, the distance involved through necessary circuitous route is 45 miles. The saving of 21 miles one way or 42 miles per round trip is an important consideration in hauling the tonnage required from the mine to the school.

The Principal naturally is hesitant about starting to lay in a stock of this coal (which is of little use for hand-firing) until your local agent receives official notification from you about the stoker installation and so I would appreciate if you could let your local agent have this information as early as possible.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

Dear Sir:

Night watchman / Old Sun School

While, as in other Indian residential schools no time and labour is spared here in the safety and welfare of the children I am wondering if your Department would consider allowing us a grant of $40.00 per month for six months to engage the services of a night watchman.

My reasons for this request are:

a) For the general welfare and safety of the children.

b) While the installation of a mechanical stoker is a fuel and labour saver this machine none the less does require periodical checks as clinkers must frequently be removed or shaken up.

c) While we encourage our graduates to visit their school we do find others wandering hither and yon in the late evenings and, in my opinion, an hourly inspection of barns and outbuildings as well as the main plant would be most assuredly in the interests of the Government.

d) Our increased pupilage to one hundred and thirty warrants strict vigilance twenty four hours of the day.

e) Should the Department accede to this request I will employ Bill Weasel Child - an ex-pupil of 20 yrs, and I think you may agree a reliable and hard working chap. Apart from giving him employment for the winter he should earn a small grub stake for the spring and summer's work.

Should you consider this claim feasible may this letter be endorsed or a covering letter forwarded to the Department for their consideration.

Yours truly,

E.S.W. Cole.

Do hereby for ourselves, and on behalf of the Indian owners of the said Reserve, request that a sum not exceeding Six hundred Dollars, be paid out of money standing to the credit of this Band, for the purpose of assisting in the re building of a skating rink at each of the Residential Schools located on the Blackfoot Reserve, The sum of Three hundred dollars to the Crowfoot School and Three hundred dollars to the Old Sun School. Accounts to pass thru the Indian Office.

Signed and sealed in the presence of

Indian Agent

Form No. LA 514

H.M. H.M. H.M. M
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

I beg to enclose herewith a Resolution of the Blackfoot Band in the sum of $600, to be divided evenly between the Crowfoot Indian School and the Old Sun Indian School, for the assistance in re-building the skating rinks, which are in very deplorable condition.

(Received) W.P.L. Pugh,
Superintendent.

Ottawa, November 3, 1948.

Re: Old Sun's Indian Residential School,
Blackfoot Indian Agency,
Gleichen, Alberta.

Referring to our memorandum of August 19th, with reference to the above, you are advised as follows:

On the occasion of a recent visit to the Blood Reserve, our Mr. Haggard visited the above and examined the domestic hot water equipment. The following report and recommendations are a result of the investigations carried out.

The domestic hot water heating and storage equipment consists of one upright boiler approximately 23" in diameter by 5'-0" high with 24" diameter grates and 52"-7" diameter tubes. This unit is connected to an upright domestic hot water storage tank 43" in diameter by 9'-6" high. The boiler tubes were cleaned last March and since the time that Mr. Haggard's memorandum was received, the pipe connections between the boiler and tank have been disassembled and cleaned. Some new pieces of pipe were installed and at present the operation is more or less satisfactory.

The boiler tubes and piping connections had become encrusted with scale, due to some extent to the hard water, but largely to the fact that no control of the water temperature was provided.

The draft door of the boiler was missing and when located, was found to be so badly warped that it was impossible to obtain a good fit. This results in the fire burning uncontrolled. At times when the hot water demand is light, the water temperature becomes critical and steam forms in the upper part of the boiler shell. Since there is no pressure relief valve on the system, an element of danger exists. It was also observed that a valve between the return connection from the hot water tank and the return connection on the boiler had been installed and was partially closed, thus throttling circulation between the two units.

Due to such a combination of circumstances, rapid scale formation has taken place. It has been demonstrated beyond doubt, that when domestic water is heated to a point exceeding 140 degrees, undue scaling is the inevitable result.

Since the expense of re-tubing the boiler has been incurred and since, with the exception of the draft door, the boiler appears to be in relatively good condition, it is felt that this unit could be used until further scaling reduces its efficiency to the point where new equipment is warranted, provided that the following revisions and additions are carried out.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
1. Provide and install an approved pressure relief valve set to release at 65 lbs per square inch and located where indicated on the drawing.

2. Provide a new draft door for the boiler or repair the existing door in a manner suitable so that it may be closed tightly.

3. Provide a coal blower to be controlled by an Aquestat set on the supply line from the boiler to the tank. This Aquestat shall be arranged to control the operation of the blower so that it will keep the water temperature within a reasonable limit, thereby giving protection from scale due to over-heating.

4. Re-arrange and replace some of the piping between the boiler and tank and remove the gate valve on the re-circulating line.

If the above operations are carried out, it is considered that the existing equipment can be expected to give some additional years of service. Then a new heater is required, the blower and Aquestat can be re-used to the same purpose as hereinbefore outlined.

The drainage system was brought to the attention of our officer during his visit. It was reported and verified by our officer, that the roof drains carrying off the roof water, were of a design which permitted particles of tar and gravel to be carried into the system during rain storms. This has resulted in blockages to some parts of the underfloor drains and in some cases has caused a back-up from the sanitary waste from the principal's quarters. It is our intention after a further study has been given to this part of the investigation, to report more fully and make a recommendation which it is hoped will provide a solution.

T. S. Mills
Chief Engineer
