November 17, 1948.

Colonel Neary:

Old Sun Indian Residential School:

Yesterday I looked into part# of this school and had a short talk with the Principal and later with Mr. Superintendent Pugh who expressed satisfaction with present conditions.

The Alberta School Inspector visited the school recently, but not since the appointment of the newest teacher who replaces one whose adjustment to residential school routines was declared inadequate.

The Principal is pleased with the new classroom formed from the room where a platform was originally built in. He found that the floor under the platform was harder to surface than anticipated. The present positioning of the blackboard that was installed should be corrected.

I noted that a good type of toilet seat has been installed in the boys' basement, but that the five bowls are not partitioned singly. One bowl was covered with a plank, as though it were plugged. In another there was a piece of wrapping paper. I did not see any toilet tissue. You are aware of the theory that prompts these distasteful observations.

In the laundry the 10 H.P. pressure boiler is not used because (1) no employee is certified to attend to it and (2) the drier is said to be surplus to requirements. "A good heating stove would be better in its place." I think that a survey of laundry practices in this school should be taken.

The Principal made the suggestion that the curriculum is perhaps, unsuited to the needs of most pupils, but rather than tinker with this, I urge a stronger attempt to place the institutional activities on a truly instructional basis so that agriculture, machine-tending, sewing, cooking, laundry work and physical education may be properly integrated with the present book-work. Some adjustments in the last would follow.

On the evening of my visit it was "movie" night and a number of adults, Indian and White, were in attendance. Community relations appear good and we should look to develop the school as a community centre for education and recreation for resident and day pupils (and ex-pupils). A start along these lines is seen at Crowfoot.

It is gratifying to learn that Mr. Superintendent Pugh has had conversations with the Alberta School Inspector looking toward the prospect of obtaining instructors in practical subjects who will spend part of their time at the two local Indian educational centres and part at nearby white schools.

G.A.F. Clark.

Dear Sir:

Electric pump, 110 Volt A.C.
Bruce Robinson Electric Co., Calgary....$75.00

For many years a hand pump was used in this school for the purposes of:

a) Drawing rain water from the reservoir under the laundry room.
b) Washing out bad drains (and there are many of them).
c) For frequent necessary changes of water in the boilers.

Note: Owing to a break in the drains-leading-in-close proximity to the reservoir under the laundry room, drain-refuse-water runs into the rain reservoir and in consequence this must be cleaned frequently and it is practically impossible to use the ancient method of hand, rope and a pail and then have to carry the water up seven steps to be emptied.

I attach herewith a slip of information from the Bruce Robinson Company of Calgary, showing this Sump pump, which would be admirable for our use, at $75.00.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Night Watchman, Old Sun School, Gleichen, Alta.

The Principal of the above school reports that the new stoker recently installed is doing a good job and that the buildings are very comfortable this winter as a result. However, the hopper of the stoker needs to be filled approximately every 24 hours which imposes an undue amount of night work on the school engineer who is required to do a full tour of duty during the day. In view of this, the Principal requests that provision be made for a night watchman at this school during the period 1st November - 31st March annually.

I wish to support strongly this request of the Principal, not only because of the need for someone to look after the night firing but also for general security reasons. Admittedly the school building proper is supposed to be fireproof, but the barns and outbuildings are not, and some unauthorized wanderer from the nearby village or Reserve might do considerable damage if not detected through the medium of periodic patrol and inspection during the winter nights. Further, with the authorized pupilage now at 130 I suggest that the expense involved in providing a night watchman for 5 months of the year is not unreasonably heavy.

I shall be glad, therefore, if you will give this request of the Principal favourable consideration and advise me as to what you are prepared to do in the matter.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

ATTENTION: Mr. W.P.B. Pugh - Superintendent

Gentlemen:

We thank you for your letter dated February 14th, relative to the stoker recently installed at the Sun Indian School. The delay in replying to your letter is due to the fact that we have been trying to locate the Clinker Tongs for this machine. We finally found them and they went forward to you via prepaid transport yesterday, on a no-charge basis.

With regards to your remark relative to the Hopper of the stoker we installed, may we advise that this stoker is designed with a Hopper which will carry 780 lbs. of coal. Normally this amount of coal will be handled by this burner for a six to eight hour period. If you were to have a Hopper on this machine guaranteed to have coal for eight hour operation, during very severe weather it would have to be designed to carry 3,120 lbs. of coal. We believe you will agree that this would be out of all proportion as to the size of the stoker, and then too, it would severely handicap the operator of the burner in his duties of filling the Hopper. We have quite a number of these machines operating in this area now, in industrial uses, and the Hopper supplied with the stoker you have is correctly proportioned for the size of the burner.

Your remarks are noted that a close check was kept on the hours of operation of the stoker, and the Hopper emptied itself in two and one half hours. This is rather exceptional, but it is probably due to the very severe weather you encountered during last month. We do not believe you will experience any difficulties with the size of the Hopper on the stoker under normal operation.

May we have your comments.

Yours truly,

I beg to state as I have previously advised that we are constantly having a near shortage of water at the Old Sun School.

In discussing the matter with the local well driller Mr. A. Rasmussen, he stated he cleaned one well out some fifteen years ago and he thought the cleaning of both out at a cost of $60.00 each would be well worth while. I beg to recommend having this done.

For your information over the original well or well No. 1 there is a solid brick building built with the necessary holes in the roof for ordinary cleaning purposes but Mr. Rasmussen stated that the building was too high for his machine to set up if he thought it was necessary to drill the well a little deeper.

I asked the local house mover if he would remove the brick building but he stated he would not take on the job of moving the solid brick building.

Under the circumstances it is possible that a further expenditure might be incurred for the lowering of the roof on this brick building in order that the well drill could be set up the same. This would be time and material and I am unable to obtain an estimate and it is possible that it might not be necessary but if it is I will further advise.

RE: Additional Accommodation
Old Sun School

With reference to the increased accommodation required at the Old Sun School this coming fall as you and the Department are both aware of, I beg to submit an estimated cost that will give this accommodation for the expected increase this fall 1949 and also 1950.

The proposal is to use the present sewing room for a class-room which measures 20'12" x 20'9", this room is well lighted with windows extending the full length of the room facing west. It is proposed to move the sewing room up into the Sun Porch up-stairs at present not used. This Sun Porch measures 7'8" x 17'3" which is also exceptionally well lighted, adjoining is a small room 9'10" x 9'4", which in the past has been used for catch-all storage, and can be used in conjunction.

In the heating of the Sun Porch apparently according to local plumber Mr. L. Michael there was insufficient radiation installed and the radiation froze some years ago and has not been used since. Mr. Michael estimates the cost of installing sufficient radiation to be $246.00. He is confident that this will keep the Sun Porch warm in all climatic conditions.
Col. B. F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Additional Accommodation - Old Sun Residential School

On a recent visit to the Blackfoot Reserve it was indicated that there was no need for a day school in the vicinity of the Old Sun Residential School. This institution can care for a larger enrollment, and, as nearly all the families on that part of the reserve are Protestants, it is only necessary to make some changes in the building to supply necessary classrooms. Superintendent Pugh has written, as per the attached, and indicated what work and material are required. The estimated cost is $500.00.

The Principal of the school, Mr. Cole, has submitted a statement, copy attached, which shows the number presently enrolled and the expected enrollment for the school year 1949/50. With these known facts, I recommend that authority be given to make the necessary changes.

The quotation by the plumber Mr. Michael is the only one that is definite, and, as there are no other plumbers within fifty miles, I believe this should be accepted. As for other work and material, Mr. Pugh can get this material locally and I believe obtain the services locally of very good carpenters, Messrs. Kelly and Reid, who have done nearly all the work on the reserve for some years.

I hope it is possible to give him authority to proceed with this work at the commencement of the summer holidays.

G. A. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Referring to previous correspondence on the above subject (your file 758-5 (E.1)), I send you hereunder an extract from a letter, dated 20th August, 1949, received today from the Principal of Old Sun School:

"I feel strongly the Indian Affairs Branch should authorize a grant for a night watchman at this school, for reasons stated in previous communications and others, for e.g. This school stands at the intersection of well travelled cross roads, also barely 2 miles from the town of Gleichen. I mention this now as I have to report that outside boys got into the senior girls dormitory by ladder some weeks prior to school closing. It would be useless to say a night watchman could prevent the outside men and boys from roaming around the school at night time, but at all events, a watchman on the job would most certainly stop others entering into the school grounds near the school, a mile before the main road. I would not request these additional governmental services; but, I feel, and I am sure you agree, that were we have 130 children living under one roof, their safety and comfort demand our constant vigilance."

In view of the above factors it is strongly urged that the matter be reconsidered and that a nightwatchman be authorized for Old Sun School even though the main building is reasonably fireproof.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent."

Canon H. G. Cook, Superintendent,
Indian Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
writes us as follows:

"The following is an extract from a report just received from the Principal of the above School regarding the drains in the building:

"'In the centre of the Boys' Washroom there is a drain with the usual brass cover which lifts off easily but underneath it is a solid block of concrete. Every drop of water gravitates to this spot and this washroom always has a puddle of water in the centre of the floor every hour of the day. Sixty boys cannot wash four or five times a day without spilling some water.

"'In the Boys' Playroom adjoining the above washroom we have precisely the same thing.'

"Perhaps you will be good enough to have a representative of the Engineering Services of your Department look into the matter of these drains the next time he is in the vicinity of Gleichen."

Please let me have a report from you regarding the above. We do not appear to have received similar information previously.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division."
Colonel B. F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary:

The hot water required in the above School is now heated by a jacket heater. This is satisfactory during the summer season when the main heating plant for the building is not in operation but it is wasteful in fuel and labour during the heating season when water might well be heated in the low pressure steam heating plant.

Following investigation and inquiries we are informed that a satisfactory solution would be the installation of an indirect steam-fed heater consisting of a cast-iron shell and removable copper tube element, having a capacity to heat water at the rate of 500 gallons per hour through a range of 100 degrees (40 degrees to 140 degrees) and equipped with a temperature control valve. We are informed that the heat absorbed in this equipment would still leave ample reserve boiler horsepower for any reasonable overload on the heating plant.

We understand that the cost of provision and installation of the equipment described would be between $400.00 and $500.00 and we shall appreciate if you can allot funds for the early execution of this service.

Will you please advise us what you are prepared to do in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Dear Major Mackay:

Re: Nightwatchman - Old Sun Anglican Indian Residential School, Gleichen, Alberta.

During our discussion in your office on 2nd September, 1949, I pointed out various factors which appear to warrant the authorization of a nightwatchman at the above School.

We now have received a report from this School advising that under normal winter conditions 250 lbs. of local (Blackfoot Reserve) coal are consumed per hour in the heating plant and that the capacity of the hopper of the Stoker is 750 lbs. of this coal. This means that under normal winter conditions the hopper must be re-filled every three hours during the night and more frequently under severe winter conditions. I am certain you will agree that it is unreasonable to expect any member of the staff who is employed continuously throughout the day to get up and shovel 750 lbs. of coal every 3 hours, or more frequently, during the night.

If, notwithstanding all the factors presented to you, the fact that the main school building is classified as "fireproof" renders it impossible for you to authorize a "nightwatchman" it is suggested that a night "fireman" be authorized as is now done for certain schools. Such an employee could, of course, do nightwatchman duties generally as well as fire the boilers and, in consequence, the present unsatisfactory situation would be remedied.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Recently General Turner made a visit of inspection to the Old Sun School and I thought you might be interested in some of his observations as quoted from his report:

"Repairs - The Principal suggests that the Indian Affairs Branch be asked to hire a couple of men for about a month each spring to carry out various carpentry, etc. repairs beyond the capacity of personnel on School Staff and which fall in the category of responsibility of the Department under their "Formula". I consider this a sound suggestion which, if adopted, would tend to keep the building in a better state of repair.

Wells - Both have been cleaned out but No. 1 was found to contain an old section of casing which could not be removed. So far they appear to be working satisfactorily, but a longer period of trial is necessary before it can be determined whether they must be replaced by a new well.

Windmill - This is still out of action (for pumping water at the barn) because it has been impossible to get anyone to take on the repair job to date.

Heating Plant - A Mr. Clarke from Regina (presumably representing the engineering branch of Department of Mines and Resources) visited the School on 8th of October. He stated that he favours the installation of a stoker (with large hopper) on the second boiler to supplement the first boiler during the heating season. An order has been placed by the Agency Superintendent for repairs to the asbestos lagging of both boilers.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Old Sun's Indian Residential School,
Gleichen, Alberta.

With reference to your notation of October 29th on Major MacKay's memorandum dated October 27th in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

The original specification outlining the laundry equipment for this school was written in 1929 and called for a washer, tumbler dryer and extractor for use in connection with laundry operations. The tumbler dryer was to be served by a steam line from the 10 horsepower high pressure laundry boiler.

Since the high pressure laundry boiler has been changed to operate on low pressure, and arranged to heat domestic hot water, no high pressure steam is available for the tumbler dryer.

Therefore unless it is contemplated to install a high pressure boiler in the near future, the tumbler dryer is of no use. If the Principal wishes to remove this unit to provide more space in the laundry room, we see no reason why it should not be unbolted from its present position and moved to any convenient storage space in the basement. Care should be taken to protect the dryer and its gearing assembly from rust, as it is conceivable that it may be desired to use this unit in the event that a new high pressure boiler is installed at some future time.

Dear Canon Cook:

Old Sun's Residential School

Please find attached a self-explanatory letter in reply to the point raised by you concerning the tumbler dryer at the above school.

May the Engineer's report be returned here when you have noted its contents.

We have also received a further report concerning the mechanical services at this school reading as follows:

"The report outlines in some detail, certain heating discrepancies together with blockages to the drainage system and is accompanied by a rough sketch of the boiler room. The boiler room sketch shows no piping of any kind and merely outlines approximate locations of the various items of equipment.

From the information received, it is not possible to make a definite recommendation or to prepare the necessary plans and specifications covering the necessary operations.

We are therefore writing Mr. Perrie requesting him to provide the data which is lacking and upon receipt of same, we will prepare our recommendation together with plans and specifications covering the requirements".

This means that the Engineer Services will be preparing plans and specifications in order that the necessary repairs can be carried out if possible during this winter. I believe that this clarifies the point raised in your letter of October 25.
With regard to the Principal's suggestion concerning repairs, we provide each year a considerable sum for each school and it would be necessary for the Principal to provide a specific list of jobs which he wants done and the materials which he wishes the Department to provide. In other words, we could not allow the Principal's suggestion to be followed without some control over expenditures insofar as labour and materials are concerned.

I would like to discuss this labour point with you on your next visit to this office.

November 8, 1949.

With reference to your notation of October 29th on Major MacKay's memorandum dated October 27th in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

The original specification outlining the laundry equipment for this school was written in 1929 and called for a washer, tumbler dryer and extractor for use in connection with laundry operations. The tumbler dryer was to be served by a steam line from the 10 horsepower high pressure laundry boiler.

Since the high pressure laundry boiler has been changed to operate on low pressure, and arranged to heat domestic hot water, no high pressure steam is available for the tumbler dryer.

Therefore unless it is contemplated to install a high pressure boiler in the near future, the tumbler dryer is of no use. If the Principal wishes to remove this unit to provide more space in the laundry room, we see no reason why it should not be unbolted from its present position and moved to any convenient storage space in the basement. Care should be taken to protect the dryer and its gearing assembly from rust, as it is conceivable that it may be desired to use this unit in the event that a new high pressure boiler is installed at some future time.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Old Sun's Indian Residential School,
Glenchen, Alberta.

Further to our memorandum dated the 7th of December in connection with the above, we are in receipt of additional inspection data from Mr. Perrie.

We have studied this data together with that contained in his report of the 12th of October and it is evident that the plumbing and drainage system is in a serious state of disorder.

Some discrepancies in connection with the heating system have been pointed out, but these do not appear to be abnormal. However, claims that the existing stoker is unsatisfactory are not substantiated and Mr. Perrie's suggestion that an additional bin feed type of stoker be installed under the second boiler, requires further clarification.

The underfloor drains are said to be blocked solid. It is claimed that deposits of tar and gravel from the roof have entered the system through unroiled roof hoppers and have lodged in the fittings and the soil pipe system. All efforts to clear the soil lines have been unsuccessful and there are many instances of flooding in the basement. This results in an unsanitary condition which could develop into a serious health hazard. Mr. Perrie concludes his report by stressing the need of immediate action.

There is no record of any plumbing or drainage plans; therefore an investigation should be carried out to find where the underfloor drains are located. After having made preliminary sketches on the job, it will be necessary to break into the basement floor slab and open the drainage lines at strategic points in order to determine the extent of the blockages.

The investigation will have to be carried out by an officer who is thoroughly familiar with this kind of work and it will involve the assistance of one plumber and the necessary labour in connection with breaking up certain sections of the floor slab and disconnecting some of the drain lines.

Following this detailed examination, it will be possible to make a definite recommendation and to prepare plans and specifications on which tenders may be based. There is no doubt that an inspection of this kind would result in a worthwhile saving.

We desire approval to make detailed plans as outlined above at which time the necessary instructions will be issued.

Chief.

Patented Calrod (Sheathed Wire) Elements

Electric cookery has been denied many homes because of the persistent expense due to service and replacement of the heating elements.

Exhaustive experiments and tests have been conducted in the Research Laboratories of the Canadian Cement Electric Co., Limited, in an endeavour to produce an electric range element which would be practically indestructible. The element here illustrated is the outcome of these experiments. The heating element wire is surrounded by an insulating powder and enclosed in a metal tube or sheath. The element sections are then wound into a circular form and are CAST IN SOLID IRON, thus forming a complete self-contained element which is practically indestructible.

Patented Calrod (Sheathed Wire) Oven Elements

A Tested, Superior Blackboard

Slatebestos has established a new standard of blackboard excellence by practical proof and demonstration of its durability, economy and desirability.

How Slatebestos is Made

The base of Slatebestos consists of asbestos fibre, hard minerals and cement, united under a tremendous pressure of 24,000 lbs. to the square foot.

Slatebestos has great tensile strength because of the fine, extra tough, clean, selected asbestos fibres employed in its manufacture, which preclude any tendency to buckle or warp.

Slatebestos contains a special, high grade cement mixture with hard minerals, which improve with time. In fact, it actually becomes tougher and harder the longer it is used.

Slatebestos is as hard as rock, possesses extreme density with almost no expansion. It is built solid throughout its full 1/2" thickness.

Perfect Writing Surface and Color

The writing surface of Slatebestos is produced through a series of liquid blackboard surfacing coats, which penetrate the body of the board. The result is to apply each coat and then rub it down, thus building up the incomparable, velvet-like, non-reflecting, dark slate color writing surface.

The result is ideal for rapid legible writing. The chalk marking surface contains just enough "slip" to cut crayons without noise and makes a clean, white, sharp mark, which can be plainly seen from all parts of the schoolroom without eyestrain. Erasures can be made easily and rapidly.

MORE ENDURING: Slatebestos actually improves with age. It will render years of satisfactory service. It is fire-resistant and asbestos and related to Slatebestos is the greatest fire-resisting and enduring blackboard on the market today.

Tank in Basement

In Figure 5 we show a splendid model for installing tanks.

It is best to support tank on strong scaffolding in basement although it may be hung from joists. If the structure is built if building is strong enough to support the weight (over half a ton) without settling. A cesspit can very easily be built to drain contents into.

Tank Under Basement

Basement installations must be carried out in such a way as to avoid any possibility of leakage. An ordinary plunger pump will satisfactorily empty tanks up to 375 gallons capacity. In installations, as in schools, should empty tanks fitted with heavy duty pump. Chimney Ventilation is possible when there are no other openings above our connection into chimney.

Other installations can be arranged. Correspondence invited.

Dear Sir:

We understand that you are in the market for a quantity of School furniture, and we enclose herewith, one of our catalogues, and literature illustrating our lines.

The prices quoted in the catalogue are, of course, subject to discount for quantities, but as we are not in possession of the specifications of your requirements, we cannot give you exact prices. We have in Calgary, samples of desks etc., and if necessary we could bring one or two on to Gleichen for your inspection.

The Canada Seating Co. is the official Supply House for the Saskatchewan School Trustees' Association, and has also supplied considerable quantities of desks etc., to the Calgary and other large School Boards. We specialize in steel-pressed school furniture, believing this far superior to the cast-iron. However, if you would prefer cast-iron, we can quote you prices on it. The Secretary,
Indian Residential Schools Com.,
Bible House,
Winnipeg,

Dear Sir:

Mr. Gooderham, Mr. Gibney and I have been over the internal arrangement of the school this week, and there are two things which we thought would be worth while taking up with you.

The first is concerning the beds for the dormitories. We thought that it would be very much nicer to have brown enamel beds than the usual white. The white has a habit of getting chipped and looks horrible when that happens. Then everything in the room is white, except the wood work, and we thought that the brown would relieve the general appearance. If the order has not already been filled, our suggestion would be that the brown be purchased instead of white.

The next is concerning the mattresses. We hear that in some schools, ticks to be filled with straw have been provided. Now, if this should be the case here, it would mean considerable delay in the opening of the school, and very inconvenient, for there is hardly any straw in the district. What little the farmers have is being carefully conserved to help out the problem of feed for this winter. Mr. Gooderham said that he did not know where we could purchase straw within a good many miles of the school. If at all possible, we would suggest that the regular filled mattresses be provided.

With kindest regards,
Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd) John W. House,
Acting Principal.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith you will find a copy of a letter just received from the Rev. John W. House, B.A., Acting Principal of the Old Sun School, and I commend to your sympathetic consideration his request for brown enamel beds for the Old Sun School, instead of the usual white ones, and also his request for mattresses.

If the beds have already been ordered, no further action need be taken in connection with that part of Mr. House's letter, but the lack of straw in that part of the country this year, appears to me to make the provision of mattresses an absolute necessity.

The furnishing of the new Old Sun School will, I trust, be completed at an early date, as some of the agents who were engaged some time ago and fully expected to begin duty at the 1st of September, have expressed their concern at the delay and the inconvenience to which they are being subjected through failure to draw any salary. Any steps, therefore, which you may be able to take to complete the furnishing of this building and to make it ready for occupation, will be deeply appreciated by our Commission.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:-

I have just been informed by the Acting Principal of the Old Sun School that no equipment whatever has been provided for the chapel, and I write to ascertain what steps have been taken by your Department in this connection. If the seating accommodation has not yet been ordered, I trust that this step may be taken immediately, as it will scarcely be possible to make any use of the chapel until this accommodation has been provided. There are certain furnishings for the chancel and sanctuary which our Society is quite prepared to provide, but it seems to me that the major and more permanent fixtures, such as a Communion table (5' long 3' high 2½' wide) reading desk, lectern, etc., should be provided by your Department, and I shall be glad to know if you will provide these for the Old Sun School.

The delay in opening this school on account of the lack of various furnishings is causing our Commission considerable inconvenience, and I trust that the above matter may receive your prompt and sympathetic consideration.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

We thank you for your order of October 1st, covering goods required for the Old Sun School, Gleichen, Alta. The goods are being assembled and we expect to make shipment of the complete order about October 21st. There is no delivery date specified on the order and we sincerely trust that the date we have mentioned will be entirely satisfactory.

The order calls for 6 #171 Beds, White Enamel finish, with Rubber Tired Casters. We would like to point out that the #171 Bed is made with 26" elevation, and if used with 4" Rubber Tired Casters, is much too high. As we have had some complaints on this score, we are taking the liberty of supplying, in this instance, #171 Beds, with shorter legs, so that when used with 4" Rubber Tired Casters the elevation will be the same as our standard Hospital Beds. This does not alter the appearance of the bed as the height of the Head and Foot Ends will be the same as the regular bed.

The order also calls for 20 #4000 Beds, size 2'6 x 5'6, which we presume is the inside measurement? These beds are required for "Dormitories" and we take it that the 20 additional beds, required for the Dormitory on the Top Floor, are to be the same size? We are, therefore, supplying 40 #4000 Beds, in this special length, and if we have not interpreted the order correctly we will appreciate hearing from you before the goods are despatched.

We will have the goods consigned to "G. H. Gooderham, Esq., Indian Agent, Gleichen, Alta." and forward invoices, in triplicate, and Bill of Lading, to him, in accordance with your instructions.

Again thanking you for this order, and awaiting your further commands, we remain.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

On August 13th last, I wired to your Department recommending that the Indian Agent of the Blackfoot Agency be authorized to purchase cooking utensils, dinner set, and other crockery ware required for the residence of the Principal of the Old Sun School. In a letter from the Principal dated Oct. 5th, he states that nothing has been done about this, and that neither Mr. Gooderham the Agent, nor himself, have had any word from your Department about it. As there are no cooking utensils whatever, and no crockery ware for this part of the building, I beg to repeat my recommendation that the Indian Agent be authorized by telegram to secure all that is necessary.

Further, in the same letter, the Principal directs attention to the need of three kitchen chairs, and also to the need of an electric stove for the residence. He states that in the construction of the building no provision was made for any other type of stove, and mentions the fact that there is no chimney in the kitchen, but that it has been wired purposely for an electric range. At the present time all the cooking is done upon an old broken stove in the basement. This condition, I feel, should be altered at the earliest moment possible.

In the same letter the Principal states that no bedroom chairs have been provided for his residence. There are four bedrooms, and I beg to recommend that the Indian agent be authorized by wire to secure at once these and all the other items enumerated above.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

The Superintendent of Education,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

In my requisition for school supplies covering this present quarter for Old Sun School, I asked for a school clock similar to that shown on page 76 of Osborne's catalogue. As I have not received this, Mr Gooderham, our Indian Agent, told me to write you and explain our situation.

We are commencing school on Monday Dec. 2nd, and have no clock in the whole building. The co-ordination of all our work will have to depend upon the various wrist watches carried by the members of my staff until we get a clock to set school time.

We really should have one big clock to hang in the hall to act as standard time for the school. Then as the class rooms are off at either end of the building, we ought to have two small inexpensive desk clocks for the teachers.

I imagine you know already how impossible it would be to run one of these schools with half a dozen different times in the building, so I need not say more about my problem.

I am, Sir,
Your obedient Servant,

John W House.
Principal.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Ottawa, December 9, 1930.

Sir:

The Principal of the Old Sun Indian Residential School requests that clocks be supplied—one for use in the hall and two for use in the classrooms. In this connection I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase of a wall clock of the type as described in catalogue No. 16 of F. E. Osborne, Calgary, the price of which is quoted at $12.85. It is considered that wall clocks of a similar but smaller type would be the most satisfactory for the classrooms, and you may also arrange for the purchase of two of these clocks. Please give the matter of the purchase and delivery of the clocks your early attention.

After the purchase has been made, you should arrange to have the clocks forwarded to the school, and you should also obtain an itemized account, in duplicate, covering the cost. This account you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,

Dear Captain Gooderham,

September 11, 1928

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 6th inst. and the petition from the Blackfoot Indians, I beg to say that a copy of this petition was forwarded with my letter of the 6th inst.

The petition is a fairly unanimous feeling of the Indians, in fact, no Indian who was approached refused to sign and in many instances they voluntarily came and signed the petition.

I am sure that the Band is prepared to assist in the erection of the School on the condition that the cost will eventually be met from Parliamentary Appropriation.

January 27th, 1931.

Dear Doctor Scott:

Answering your personal letter of the 19th inst. in regard to Old Sun School, there are at present 73 pupils attending and it is not likely that this number will increase very much.

The bake oven was used for the first time yesterday and the Principal is satisfied with it. On enquiry I learned that it bakes well but it was necessary to make two bakings to meet the requirements. The electric bread mixer is good and certainly saves a lot of labour. The bake room is too small for all the equipment in it and the main source of trouble is a large metal dough trough. It is twice the size needed and stands in the way of workers. I believe a smaller wooden trough will answer the purpose much better. However, I am taking an experienced master baker to see the room and he should be able to suggest minor changes which will help the workers.

The Staff is mostly new to the work but the school is running smoothly and Mr. House will shortly have a good organization.

Weather continues fine and warm. Light influenza is going about but so far, the Indians are mostly free from it. Mrs Gooderham joins in sending our regards to you.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Indian Commissioner at Regina, he informs me that in a report on his recent visit to the Old Sun School "he made a note of the fact that the cattle there were not what are desired", and recommends that when others are procured these should be of the Holstein class.

As to the need of a better strain of milch cows than the school possesses at present there is no doubt. Whether these are Holsteins or Shorthorns I am of the opinion that it does not greatly matter, but as our Society has provided the school with a thoroughbred bull of the Shorthorn breed Mr. Minielly, who is our Farm Instructor and a graduate of the Ontario Agricultural College at Guelph, has advised that any stock purchased should be of the same class.

To inaugurate a system of mixed farming which would meet the requirements of the school, somewhere between twelve and sixteen cows would be required, and I write to ascertain if your Department will come to the assistance of our Society in providing not less than ten of these. Without your assistance I can see no possibility of their being secured for some time to come, and if you will be good enough to give us a start in this way I shall be very grateful indeed and very deeply obliged.

Believe me,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to take the liberty of drawing your attention to the following matters in connection with our School, and I ask for your kind consideration in regard to them.

Firstly, As you know we have now a very complete new Stock barn, and we are very anxious to have it filled with a good herd of Milch cows. At present we have only two good cows, which we purchased ourselves last month. The purchase was made from the returns of four useless animals from a milking point of view. These new cows are pure bred Holsteins, and costing us $100.00 each. We have, besides these, six grade cows of more or less value. From the latter we could raise some animals for Beef purposes. Our great need is, however, a good stock of milkers. To complete our herd with what we have already got, we require ten new cows.

Secondly, I may say that through your Department, all our stock were T.F. tested, including a Shorthorn bull. Three two-year-old heifers reacted, and we had to let them go to a cattle buyer for $32.00 for the lot. With this money, we anticipate buying a registered Berkshire Boar.

If your Department can come to our assistance in this very important matter, we should feel that our barn was being used to the very best advantage. At the present time, I am rather ashamed to have visitors come and find us in the position we are in. Our great aim here is to have sufficient butter and milk for the children as well as the staff, all the year round. In having these very necessary things, we shall feel that we are doing something to build up the physique of the children.

Our Commission is doing all that it finds itself able to do at the present time for our Farm. I may say that outside the new Barn your Department has not done anything for the farm, except to make a grant last year of $100.00 for fence posts. We are very grateful for what the Dept. has done, but we feel that we must ask for assistance in this very vital matter.

I am enclosing you a few of the items of expenditure by the Commission during the last two years; just giving the larger items.

Household Equipment: I also beg to call your attention to the fact that our present Kitchen Range is old, with parts that cannot be repaired, and too small for the school. Our Kneading trough, which was granted last year with our new equipment, is made of...
To Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

wood, and is, therefore, very difficult to keep in a sweet condition in spite of every effort on the part of those responsible for the baking. Complaints have been made to me and I find that they are reasonable. If it is possible to have the present Kneading trough metal-lined, it would do, but if not, we should be supplied with an all-metal trough.

I have been requested to write you in regard to these matters at once. I regret that our Agent is away at present in Ottawa. If he is still there when this letter reaches you, I believe that he would endorse my requests. If the matter must be held in abeyance until his return, I shall ask him to go carefully into these matters with me.

Believe me, it our aim here at the school to serve the Indian Department and our Church faithfully and well, so that I feel that the considerations I am asking at the present time, and may be asked for in the future, are with this sole object in view, that we may be the better enabled to make this Institution first class in every way.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th inst., informing me that the Department had a request from the Principal of the Old Sun School to purchase ten additional cows for that Institution. You reminded me I was informed on January 4th last, that it is not the Department's policy to supply stock for schools, but that you are convinced that this school should have more milking cows than they have at present. I am taking from your letter that you propose to supply these cows outright, if you found they were necessary.

I visited this school last week, and I saw eight cows in the stable; two Holsteins that were recently purchased by the school, I was not impressed with them, in fact they are only giving a gallon each at a milking; and six grade cows, which are not of a bad type, in fact I would consider them an average-grade Shorthorns—two of these cows are about to freshen. This will add considerably to the quantity of milk. However, I do not think that even with this additional supply in prospect there will be sufficient milk at the school. I am of the opinion that with an additional three cows, this is all that will be needed at the present time. I am not prepared, however, to leave the choice of these cows to the school authorities.

I presume the Department are anxious to treat all alike, and I wish to inform you that it was only a couple of months ago the Crowfoot School authorities found it necessary to purchase a couple of new cows, and they paid for these out of their grant, and are prepared to buy another couple cows. When they hear the Government are doing this for the Old Sun School, they will naturally want the same treatment, and I think they should have it.

It seems to me these two schools have an ample opportunity

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
opportunity to build up a herd, and not call upon the Department to spend money in this direction; as a matter of fact they should be selling milch cows at these places, instead of the Department buying them for them, especially as these schools have been in operation for so many years. I would, therefore, recommend that three cows be bought for the Old Sun School and three for the Crowfoot School.

Your obedient servant,

It is very interesting to notice the progress which is being made at the Old Sun Indian Mission of the Missionary Society of the Church of Canada in the way of improving the originally mixed grade herd. Last week the second 60-day test in the way of accreditation has been successfully passed by the government Veterinarian. Another clean test in the next 60 days means that the herd will be fully accredited according to the rules and specifications of the department of agriculture at Ottawa.

Not only will the school then have an accredited herd, but also the beginning of a fully purebred herd, as the grade cattle are being gradually fattened and butchered off and are being replaced with the dual purpose short-horn.

On January 24, 1925, the first test for T.B. was taken on the herd which proved to contain one reactor which was slaughtered immediately. It was very gratifying to receive the report from the government veterinarian that last week that not a single reactor was found.

Dear Sir:

Re - Seed Drill for Old Sun School.

The Principal of the Old Sun School has directed my attention to the urgent need of a new Seed Drill if the farming activities at this institution are to be properly carried on and developed. He states that the old drill, a LaCrosse, is now so obsolete that it is difficult almost to impossibility to get new parts or repairs. Moreover, he states that it does not seed evenly, and even misses rows from time to time. The cost of a new single disc, 20 run drill, of the latest all metal type, he estimates at approximately $225.00 f.o.b. Gleichen, and I am writing at the urgent request of our Commission to ascertain if your Department can provide this very necessary item of equipment in time for the seeding operations this Spring.

I may mention for your information that in the same letter in which the Principal asked for the seed drill, he also requested an extra team of horses, and our Commission have agreed to purchase this team at a cost of approximately $200.00. As we have also expended during the last few months approximately $500.00 for pure-bred milk cows for this School, and were confronted at the close of last year with a heavy cash expenditure in excess of cash receipts from all sources, including the per capita grants, you will understand the circumstances which have prompted our Commission to solicit your help in the purchase of the seed drill.

I shall be glad to hear from you at your earliest convenience, and remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

With regard to our conversation re the Milk herd at Old Sun School, I have made investigation and beg to report as follows:

The herd belonging to the school prior to 1927 was made up of 5 scrub milk cows, some bought in the stock yards at Calgary. Two of them were defective, one was of Holstein and Jersey stock, another was more or less of pure Holstein breed, and the other just scrub. In 1927 the Indian Commission of the M.S.C.C. sold the two defectives and bought two pure bred Holstein cows to replace them. In addition to this they bought a pure bred Holstein bull which we now have. The scrub cow was traded for a Holstein heifer later on.

This makes our present herd to consist of one old more or less Holstein, one half Jersey and Holstein, and three pure bred Holstein cows. The natural increase of these consists of five heifers, one just over a year old, and the others younger.

You will see by this that our effective strength is four good cows and one old one which will soon be useful only for breeding purposes. Our increase has been fairly normal, but the heifers are too young to be producers for the next year at least.

Now the situation that I am trying to handle is this. Within a few weeks we shall have from 80 to 90 children in this school, all of them having been living at home for over a year and in consequence under nourished. When we receive them, we shall be immediately faced with the problem of building them up to normal strength, for unless they are in good health, our time will be wasted in trying to educate them.

I thoroughly discussed the care of the children with Dr. Windsor, our Indian Reserve L.C., and she was most emphatic about the desirability of being able to give each child at least one pint of whole milk and one ounce of good butter as a minimum ration (daily).

Upon this basis we would need 13 gallons of whole milk, and 7 pounds of butter daily to provide a minimum ration for children and staff. Then, taking our present rate of production as a basis of calculation, we would require 7 cows to produce the whole milk, and 5 from which to make butter. That means that we ought to have at least a dozen cows to give us our minimum supply.

You will note that I only asked for six new cows to make our herd up to eleven. I did this because I thought that with a little more care we might possibly increase our supply per cow a little over what it now is. Assuming that this is a possibility I made the requisition of six as an absolute minimum.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Acting Principal
SIR:—

Answering yours of the 30th ult., in regard to the milk herd at Old Sun School. I attach hereto a letter from the Principal of the school and I believe you will find it to be a satisfactory explanation of the existing condition of the herd. All animals are T.B. tested and the herd is now certified by the Department of Agriculture as being free from t.b. When the animals were first tested, two reacted and had to be destroyed.

More milch cows will be needed to supply the milk when the pupils return. Rev. Mr. House has lately assumed his new duties and I have confidence in him. If the M.S.C.C. cannot supply him with more cows, we cannot expect the pupils to get all the milk they should have. In such event, I recommend that the Department purchase the cows. In this connection, I beg to submit that the Holstein breed is not my choice of breed for this school. What is needed is a dual purpose breed and if I were making the purchase, I would try to get milking Shorthorns or some breed which can be readily beefed.

Milch herds which are T.B. tested are limited in these parts—in fact, it may be necessary to go out of the Province to locate fresh milk cows of the type required. Whether it be the Department or the M.S.C.C. that purchase the cows, arrangements to do so should be made right away.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of the 15th inst., #104-1-14, in which you inform me that you have authorized Mr. Indian Agent Gooderham to purchase three cows for the Old Sun School. Only last week I received a letter from the Principal of this school dealing, in detail, with the whole question of the herd of stock now on the school premises. In reply to his communication, our Commission instructed me to authorize the Principal to take the matter up direct with the local Indian Agent, and to arrange, so far as possible, for the building up of a herd of pure-bred Holsteins. For some time our Commission desired to have at this school a herd of Shorthorns, or a dual purpose strain of stock, but the Indian Commissioner favoured the Holsteins and consequently a goodly number of Holstein animals are there at present. It seemed to our Commission that considerable expense would have to be incurred to make a complete change of the herd, and consequently it would be better to adhere to the one breed instead of having a mixture. The Principal has been authorized by our Commission to exchange some of the animals for Holsteins, and I trust that your Department may authorize Mr. Gooderham to purchase three good Holsteins as well. Sir,

I beg to submit my report for the month of May 1938.

Both schools were visited. The Old Suns school graduates put on a banquet and dance on the 11th. The banquet was at the school and the dance at Crowfoot Hall. It was a creditable performance and we were impressed particularly by the fine meal prepared by school girls under staff supervision. This school has crops and garden seeded where irrigation is available and has also broken about 50 acres to raise feed. The acreage is a bit large, I feel but we will see what is done with it.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Schools

The writer visited both residential schools in connection with repairs and improvements. The children, of course, were still on holidays and did not return until the sixth of July. The improvement and repair work to the Crowfoot school was being carried out with local labor and the acting Principal is to be commended on the class of work and the amount that he was able to do with very limited expenditure. This school was in good shape to properly care for all the pupils this year. The crop at this school was excellent and is now being threshed. At the Old Sun School the staff was concentrating on the harvesting which came off irrigated lands. This land has produced abundance of feed and a good garden as well as some threshed grain. Both schools had done well with their exhibits at the Calgary Fair and prize money was here for the pupils on their return this fall. This coming year more stress will be given to handicraft work and the general work will undoubtedly be more pleasing to the Indian pupils.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian agent.
At the Old Sun School, the irrigated farm produced 850 bushels of oats, 235 bushels of wheat, 50 tons of alfalfa, and 75 tons of hay; besides a garden which was a revelation as to what irrigation will do. For example; they raised 20 tons of potatoes; 2000 cabbages; 100 pumpkins; 100 marrows; 10 sacks of cucumbers; 50 bags each of turnips; carrots and parsnips and numerous other small vegetables.

The cattle herd totals 34 head, of which there are 20 milch cows.

Classwork and vocational work was proceeding in an orderly fashion and generally everything was quite satisfactory at this school.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Herewith my report for the month of November, 1941.

SCHOOLS

Arrangements were made with both Principals for one boy pupil to feed a calf, the property of the parent, under the scheme put out by the Alberta Junior Livestock Clubs. The boy or girl must feed, water and care for this calf from the 1st of December until the early summer when it is hoped that some competition with other clubs can be arranged and a prize given to these boys. The main reason for this is to encourage and educate these young Indians in the care and feeding of stock. At least one other, outside the schools, will also care for a calf so that we will have a local competition at any rate. An ex-pupil of the Old Sun School was sent to Calgary to take the Dominion Provincial Youth Training course in mechanics; this boy is paying his own expenses. Four pupils of this school and nine ex-pupils of the two schools were started on a 6 weeks course in farm mechanics, carpentry, blacksmithing and agriculture under supervision of the Dominion Youth Training project. This school is held in Gleichen and arrangements were made for the boys to live at Crowfoot Community Hall where the wife of the Indian caretaker supplies the meals. An allowance is given by the Government for transportation and board, and this will be turned over to this woman. The boys are getting something out of this course at very little cost to their parents.

G.H. Gooderham,

Dear Sir:

Herewith my report for the month of December, 1941.

SCHOOLS:

Both schools were visited. The writer was particularly impressed by the number of stock at the Old Sun School; there were 55 head of cattle, of which 16 cows are milking. There were three sows with three large litters of young pigs, besides 25 feeders and one boar. Two hundred odd hens were laying an average of 5 dozen eggs daily. Owing to the male staff being the manual training supervisor at Old Sun could only give a small part of his time to carpentry work. At Growfoot a good start has been made in this and the building used for this purpose has been fitted with benches and was sufficiently large to handle all those who are taking this work. More or less as an experiment and also because children had been retained in school almost continuously since summer holidays the pupils of both school got a week's holidays at Christmas time. Rations were issued to their parents and it was the first time that I have ever noted that the parent or guardian realized he had a responsibility to look after his own. The enthusiasm of getting the children out wasn't so great when they realized that they would have to feed them and keep them warm and in good health for the period that the Indian normally ran here and there all over the country. The pupils are now back in school and I believe they are mostly in good health. I have noted one thing that there was less travel to the city and fewer Indians drunk and in trouble than in former years; possibly this is due to the fact that they had to remain at home and look after their family - at any rate it was good training for the parents.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Education: Two boys are attending Gleichen High School in grade 10; they are doing alright.

There are 200 pupils at the two residential Boarding schools. They are healthy and happy. Vocational training has been improved and the calibre of the instructors satisfactory.

Classroom work always appears to be lacking in something; possibly this is due to lack of interest by the pupil but it is so easy for a teacher to get in a rut and lack that spirit which the child needs so much to retain its interest and enthusiasm. Indian children love to sing and they are good singers. We need to practice a little more psychology to get nearer the desired results.

All children who were school age and physically fit at the beginning of the term are attending the schools.

At both institutions, the farms produced ample feed for stock. Good milk herds are retained while the flocks of foal produced sufficient eggs. Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Rose Mary Lowhorn, Pupil No. 0237, of the Old Sun Indian Residential School at Gleichen, who died at the Blackfoot Hospital (place) on Jan 29th 1946.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir,

On the occasion of a recent visit to the Catholic Boarding School, on the Peigan Reserve, I have been made pleased to notice the progress made by the pupils during a comparatively very short time.

It had been complained, for some time, that the person in charge of the class was not sufficiently qualified to teach English and especially to give the true and exact pronunciation. By looking only at the results there would not seem to be much foundation to the objection, as it would be hard to find any instance of such a remarkable transformation having been more rapidly accomplished in the training of Indian children. Yet to comply with the wish of the Department, the services of an English lady teacher have been secured and she has just taken charge of the class work.

The object of my present letter is
is to call the attention of the Indian Department to the fact that there are only 20 children authorized for that school, which could furnish accommodation for 40 or even 50 pupils.

At present there are 25 children admitted in the school, with the consent of the Department, but for the 5 supplementary pupils, the usual grant is not given, the Agency providing only the rations of beef and flour for them.

At this time of the year, it would be an easy matter, by making a special allowance in the supplementary estimates, to secure the usual grant for these five children and even for other children who could be admitted before the end of the fiscal year. The school is large enough for about fifty children and it seems that it should be filled as soon as possible.

I believe that the number of children recommended for next year is 40. I would respectfully ask that, even before the end of the fiscal year, it should be allowable to admit, if possible, that number or at least 30.

It cannot be said that funds are not available as there are good many schools where the authorized number of pupils is far from being completed and cannot be completed before the end of the year. To give only one instance, I will
will point out the St. Joseph's Industrial School, Munbow, the number of pupils admitted therein being at least twenty short of the authorized number.

While visiting the school on the Peigan Reserve I could not help being struck with the poor accommodation there to be found as far as desks and blackboards are concerned. In fact they have nothing of the kind worth notice. I would therefore strongly recommend also that the Department should kindly make appropriation for 2 dozen of desks (4 of each size) and 2 large blackboards.

These of course, should be attended to at once, if it is wished not to thwart the work of the school.

Without doubt the Rev. Principal of the School shall have communicated with you, of late, on these subjects. I hope that the Department will be willing to take the matter in the most serious consideration, and grant our requests.

While the Principal of the School shall be notified, it would be a favour conferred on me, if I could also receive the information.

I have the honour to be,

&c., &c., &c.,
Emile J. Legal, Bp. of Pasla.

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 3rd instant in further reference to the admission of children to the Indian boarding and industrial schools.

In reply I beg to say that this is a matter which has for a considerable length of time been receiving the earnest and careful consideration of the officials of the Department. At the same time the suggestions offered by Your Lordship and others interested in educational work among the Indians have been gladly noted and, where practicable, acted upon.

As to the establishment of fresh air dormitories as a part of the programme of the Department in alleviating the present unsatisfactory health conditions I think that the following statement will show that Your Lordship is under a misapprehension in supposing that any discrimination against the Roman Catholic schools has been exercised.

The policy of the Department is to treat all religious bodies in a fair and equitable manner and there was no departure from this policy in the case of the Pelican school.

Dear Dr.

I have just returned today from a visit to the Agency & the schools on the Pigeon Indian Reserve and had to report as follows.

I have succeeded in improving the surroundings. The pig pen has been placed back by the barn. The original sty has been cleaned and sprinkled with lime (plenty of it too). The agent & farmer surveyed the cabins and decided they were not worth moving. Two new ones have been built and sanitary facilities arranged. The old ones torn down, filled in after a good quantity of lime was used.

The new ones are located — on the girls side at the farthest corner... on the boys side, outside the grounds 50 feet from its farthest corner from the buildings.
Sir,

Dr. Gillespie of Pincher Creek met me at Brocket Thursday September 7th, and we drove to the Roman Catholic School, where we discovered three cases of typhoid fever. We immediately took steps to find out the source of the trouble, and came to the conclusion that it was from the water in the well, as there is a pig sty with a small open yard, covered with mud and water, and the pigs were wallowing in it, about twenty (20) feet from the well and about ten (10) feet farther on was a pit closet, which was used by the boys. The soil in that locality is gravel and easily penetrated by fluids. We had the patients isolated to one of the sleeping balconies, instructed them to boil the water, have the closet removed and the pit filled in, also the pig sty placed at a greater distance away. We drove back to the Agency and left instructions for a closet to be made with a seat to lift up, and the Doctor was going to order some galvanized pails to be used, and they are to be emptied in a place a distance away from the Institution, chosen by ourselves. We also ordered a lot of lime to be used about where necessary. Dr. Gillespie was going to inoculate the rest of the inmates of the School, with typhoid vaccine, and have the water sent to be analyzed. There is another well farther away, which has not been used for a time, and Dr. Gillespie was going to have it looked into for getting the water supply. As the School is a very old building, and in an
out-of-the-way place, and I was given to understand from Mr. Markle and others, that there is a chance of them having a new one in another locality, as soon as conditions permit, I would suppose that the Department would not care to go to the extra expense of putting down another well, at the present place. I expect the Agent will communicate with the Department for further instructions.

I happened to meet Dr. Lafferty at Okotoks, who is now Provincial Health Inspector, and he said that he would have sealed bottles sent for the water, and see that it was analyzed himself.

The School was clean and as well kept as an old building of this sort could be expected.

I also visited the Church of England School and Hospital and found everything in good order, with the exception of flies coming through the windows, and I requested that they get some cheese cloth to cover the windows, which would be opened. I heard them ordering the man to get the cheese cloth, while I was there.

They are going to have all the houses on the Reserve, cleaned and fumigated before they go back to occupy them for the winter.

Rev. Mr. Haynes, principal of the Church of England School took me to look at another site for a new school. The site is admirably situated, if there is any intention of building one. His idea is to get trees planted and the ground worked up before a building is erected. Of course, I have no idea of what the Department contemplates in the matter.
I was more than pleased to find that Dr. Gillespie had returned from the war, and was back to his position again to attend to the Indians on this Reserve, as there were a great many complaints about medical attendance to the Indians during his absence. In fact I had received a letter from Agent Gunn about it sometime ago, and I wrote to Dr. Dubuc in regard to it. A copy of my reply I enclose. The people all seemed pleased that Dr. Gillespie was back again to renew his work. They had had an epidemic of measles among the Indians with a very heavy death rate.

Your obedient servant,

D. C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

In this Agency there are two Boarding Schools. The Victoria Home (Church of England) and The Sacred Heart (Roman Catholic) Boarding Schools.

The Victoria Home School is situated just off the Western Boundary of the Reserve. The Principal, Rev. W.R. Haynes, resides on the Reserve as Missionary, and the school is run by an assistant principal. This has been vacant lately but there is a new man who is to take over the duties of Principal after he has been here three months. The same objection as before still remains, too many changes and the lack of an energetic man. There have been five boys discharged from this school lately and I think it wasted money that they cannot speak better after being in school ten or eleven years. There is no farming at all done and the garden was an almost total failure last year. The outbuildings are poor and hardly worth keeping in repair.

The Sacred Heart Boarding School.

The Sacred Heart Boarding School is situated near the site of the old Agency about the centre of the reserve. The Principal, the Rev. Father Levern, the Teacher is Sister Lewis. The Staff seem efficient and the place is well kept and clean. The garden was a failure last season and no farming is done.

The effect of education on the reserve is slightly improving especially among the women.

I have been given to understand that new schools have been promised when the war is over to both denominations and under the present government it should be possible to have one Government school situated on the
best land on the reserve and self-supporting and non-denominational, the Department securing the best teachers possible and best farm instructors. This seems to me to be the only way to get the best returns for the money spent on education as well as saving the cost of one building which should pay for running expenses until it could be made self-supporting.

It is certain to me here that the present system is nearly a waste of money as the boys get no training in the care of horses and usually under no competent men as the church schools cannot afford to keep men of this description owing to lack of finances.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd inst.,
no. 1181834, re Condition of affairs at the School,
and to say in reply that it certainly caused us a
great and painful surprise, as we were not prepared
at all to receive such a sad news, for many
good reasons:

1. The Inspectors, Agents and Doctors have regu-
larly visited this School and they always had
but one voice to praise our work, and their
reports in the Annual Blue Books show that
they seemed to mean what they used to
tell us. Did not even Mr. Markle, after his last
visit here, make a personal appeal to the Indian
Department to try and build a new school for
us as soon as possible?

2. The proper time to speak about closing this
school was eight or nine years ago when the
Indians were all removed away from us and
new farms were arranged for them around
Brocket and close to the other schools who could have
believed at that time that we would have been
able to recruit any more pupils? However, in spite
of the river and of the long distance, the Indians
have kept on giving us their children and even
today, we have three pupils over the number for
whom the grant is paid.

3. I must say also that our pupils seem to appre-
ciate the care and the attention they receive
from us; they are happy, contented and quite
at home here, and at the end of their vacation they are all in a hurry to come back.

4) And now you are informing me that "in view of the very unsatisfactory condition of affairs at the Leigam R.C. Boarding School, the Dept will be forced to close it unless a very decided improvement is noted in the near future..." A thunder clap in a cloudless sky could not have made on me a stronger emotion; is it possible that we have been deceiving ourselves when, in the circumstances just mentioned, we thought that our work had not only the approval, but also the congratulation of the Department? On the 20th of last March McGunn came here with the Head Doctor and Mr. Gil. Leslie and, after having made their inspection, they claimed they were greatly pleased and praised us for the cleanliness of the house, the good manners of the children, etc., etc.

5) If, in spite of all this, it is true that you find the condition of affairs "very unsatisfactory" and wish for a "very decided improvement", kindly let us know what is unsatisfactory and what kind of improvement you want. I believe that I am entitled to say that we have always been anxious to comply with the wishes of the Department.

6) You complain that "the results do not justify the Department in continuing the expenditure incurred here". I admit, very willingly, that our work is not very encouraging nor the results so good as desired; but, on the other hand, do the other schools obtain a better success on the Indian Reserves? The transformation of an Indian race is necessarily a slow work.
after all, is even the White race perfect, after nineteen centuries of civilization and christianity?

Hoping you will kindly excuse the strong emotion which shows itself through my letter and take into consideration the few remarks I am submitting you and answer promptly and satisfactorily. I remain dear Sir,

your faithful servant,

J. Keenan, o.m.i.p.r.

REGINA, SASK., 4th April, 1929.

Sir:

I enclose herewith a report on an inspection of the Roman Catholic and Church of England schools in the Regina Agency. The report shows that excellent work is being done at the Roman Catholic School. Everything in connection with the institution was found to be in first class shape. The premises were clean. The children were in good condition and the father had reaped his first crop, which yielded 5,000 bus. wheat and 12 tons of potatoes, as well as a lot of garden truck. This goes to show what can be done with proper management. I consider that the Principal of this school should be congratulated on the manner in which he has managed this institution. There is no doubt in my mind that the boys and girls here are getting a real training.

With regard to the Church of England School, conditions have not changed and it seems too bad that this work is to suffer through absolute incompetence on the part of the management. The Indians are not receiving the proper training for their children under the management of the present principal. In the first place he is impracticable. He knows nothing about farming, which after all is the most important branch of the work to be carried on at the institution. He has in his employ Mr. Hillier, who was dismissed from our service as being incompetent, lazy, and a failure generally, and it seems to me that this school is going to get worse instead of better. I am quite aware that when the Inspector's last report went in Doctor Westgate replied to the charges therein and it was thought that we could let the matter ride for a while. This inspection, however, goes to show that there has been no improvement. Just fancy a new place of this kind, with all the equipment we have supplied, and no land ready for crop, and no summer allowing done. The Department should take serious steps in regard to this matter.

The Secretary,

Sir:

I have the honour to report on a recent inspection of the Sacred Heart Indian Boarding School on the Peigan Reserve. At the time of my inspection there were 55 children in residence. I spent practically a whole day at the school, and during that time I spent quite a little while in the two classrooms.

Mr. Bremner, the Provincial School Inspector, has recently inspected the classroom work at this school and according to his report everything is quite satisfactory. I will not dwell on this phase of the work any more than to say that both teachers are performing splendid work; especially Sister Gertrude Roy. She has been at the Blood and Peigan Schools for a great many years and I have always found her work most satisfactory. She takes a great interest in her pupils and gets splendid results. Sister St. Joan of Arc is also a good teacher, but she has not had the experience of Sister Gertrude Roy.

HEALTH:

I was very well pleased with the appearance of the children. They are certainly getting exceptionally good care and are being well looked after in every way. They receive good food and there was no sickness of any kind to be seen in the school.

The secretary,

OTTAWA.

Their clothing was clean and tidy and in looking over the stock of clothing on hand for the children, I found that they were probably better supplied than any school I have ever visited; They have five changes.

WATER SUPPLY: This is proving very satisfactory and the school has an ample supply of water. The Engineer informed me that a short time ago he wanted to clean out the tank at the spring, and he pumped for 9½ hours steadily before the reservoir was pumped dry.

They had about 400 bushels of potatoes and an abundance of all kinds of vegetables consisting of 18 different varieties.

GROUNDS: I reported on the grounds, garden, &c., of this school in June last.
